text:
12 oz. bottle. Originally reviewed 2/7/2015.
Slightly hazy deep amber. Medium white head. Medium collar.
Smells like apple juice, but a little less sweet. A little bit of an earthy aroma.

Taste is an unsweetened apple flavor. Earthy maybe isnt the right descriptor anymore. Slightly acidic. Then the sweet apple juice kicks in. Finishes like apple juice. Medium body. Well carbonated.
Its pretty good, but apple just isnt an interesting enough fruit for me.
Pours clear amber with low white head. Aroma of apple juice, light bread. Taste is apple juice, mild tart apple and green grapes in the finish. Light and smooth body with average carbonation.

Bottle 355ml vintage 2015 @ geokkjer
[Courtesy of bergstaden] Pours hazy amber/copper with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, sweet red apples and hint of vanilla. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long sweet red apple finish, Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft. 7 4 7 4 14 - 3.6

Bottle 355ml vintage 2016 @ geokkjer
[Courtesy of bergstaden] Pours deep golden/copper with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, apple and hint of sourness. Taste is medium sweet, light bitter and light sour with a long apple and malty finish. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft. 6 3 6 3 13 - 3.1

Bottle, 12oz, shared by Bergstaden. 2015 edition. An unclear, copper colored beer with a small, off-white head. Lots of apples in the initial aroma, then mashed apples tending towards diacetyl and vanilla. Candy, white sugar. Its smooth, soft and medium bodied, with flavors of mashed apples, candied apples and some vanilla. Long mashed apples finish. Pleasant indeed, perhaps with an apple cake of some kind. 7-3-7-3-14-3.4Bottle, 12oz, shared by Bergstaden. 2016 edition. Clearer than the 2015 edition, and a bit lighter in color. More mellow aroma and flavor than 2015, much less apple. Smooth and medium to full-bodied, with a mellow carbonation. Sure prefer the 2015 edition, but its a decent beer anyway. 6-3-6-3-12-3. 170311

Bottle, courtesy of bergstaden. Pours deep golden with an off-white head. Aroma of red apples, malt, fruitiness and apple peel. Flavor is sweet and malty with red apples, caramel, apple peel, apple pit and malt. Medium body, average carbonation.

This Ale totally shocked me! I am not a big into ciders at all so I was a little skeptical to buy it. I am glad I did!! It pours a copper to light amber color with a strong aroma of apples.
The taste is all apple with a dry finish. I want more!
Fall in a bottle. Not much carb but its there, pleasant apple aroma. Taste is crisp apple cider...this beer is everything I love about apple cider in beer form.

The only negative about these are that they are way too easy to drink, so you end up running out of them too quickly. Pours a hazy copper. Aroma is fresh apples with caramel malts. Taste was fresh apples, sweet on the front end, but with a dry finish, allowing you to have multiple beers for further inspection and analysis. These are phenomenal.

An ale so good it temporarily turned me into a stuttering idiot (well, more of a stuttering idiot than usual). If it werent for the New Glarus name, I wouldnt have purchased this. I dont really like cider (unless Im really drunk). Im not even very keen on apples (probably the most overrated fall offering outside of pumpkins). I was totally unprepared for how much I liked Apple Ale. Jesus H. Christ. Its basically the most crisp, delicious apple juice you could ever hope to drink. With a little booze. Does a bottle of this a day keep the doctor away? If so, sign me up.

Thanks Virby44 for the bottle! Poured into taster showing apple juice brown with half a finger of clean white foam. 

The nose shows a distinct red apple aroma on top of a bed of earthy malts. 

The palate is highly carbonated and medium bodied. Very strong apple forward flavor throughout that increases until it reaches a sharply sweet apple note (think apple pie or jolly rancher) on the finish. Upon warming, caramel malts become more apparent and blend very well with the apples. Very nice finish and probably closer to a cider in my opinion but I cant really tell the difference.

Bottle.

A- Apple juice.

A- Amber color, clear liquid, off white head.

T- Apple juice.

P- Light body, average texture, average carbonation, refreshing finish.

O- This would be a great beer for cider folks. All the good qualities of a cider mixed with the greatness that is beer. Not too sweet or fake tasting. Really well done. Simple and tasty.
Apples all over. In the nose palate and finish sweet apple mouth feel and dry finish. Very tasty.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a hazy dark orange. Aroma is apples. Flavor is a nice balance a sweet apple and a slight sour finish. Flavors is definitely green apple with some caramel. Very well done apple beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
clear copper color. Rich flavors (sweet and sour apple) with a nice finish (dry).

Saw dust, straw, light, sweet apple. Clear gold, small , creamy, white head. Medium sweet. Intense green apple, sweet cider, lively carbonation, light bitterness coming up in the finish. Very refreshing Fruit Beer, nice apple in palate, aroma seems a bit odd. Keg at the brewery, New Glarus, WI.
From Bushel and Peck. Really nails the balance between bitter and fruit sweetness. Excellent. Serving: Bottle
Tap at the brewery. Poured hazy copper. White head. Aroma was apple, sweet apple juice. Taste was sweet, tart, dry finish. Very good.

Murky brown pour which kind of looks like apple cider. Single finger white head. Aroma of apple cider. Taste is like apple cider, but as a beer. Sweet apples. You can literally taste every bit of the apple from the fruit to the peel. A little lace present. Unreal what New Glarus can do with fruit.
From a 12 oz bottle. Pours a clear gold with an off white head. Aroma of tart apples. Flavors of caramel apples. Sweet finish.
Really nice apple beer. Bottle from brewery. Yeasty and appley aroma. The taste is close to a real apple cider, minus the spices. Plenty sweet though. Tasty
Apple juice. Dark gold color. High sweetness. Low carbonation. Thin head. Very good.

Bottle, courtesy of Douglas from Portland. Thank you. Shared in Rome-Italy. Caramel hazy light, bubbles. Nose: cinnamon, amaretto, boiled apple. Mouth: sweet approach of syrup, clean and dry candy, apple. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared by ippopotamo36 (thanks Alberto!). Pours amber with a minimal head. Aroma of apple, cinnamon, amaretto, maple syrup. Flavour is very sweet, unbalanced, rough. Light body, light carbonation. Not my cup of tea.

A hazed amber ale with a thin white head. In aroma, sweet fruity apple pulp with light mineral notes, light flower perfume, nice. In mouth, a nice sweet cider like offering with Apple pulp, light mineral notes, light chalky character, refreshing. On tap at Cajun Café spring beer fest 2016.

12oz bottle. Pours a nice dark Amber golden color. Aroma is mostly apples with some caramel and toasted bread. Taste is all apple up front, nice tartness with sweet finish. New Glarus knows how to do fruit beers.

12 ounce bottle into pint glass, bottled on 7/21/2015. Pours slightly hazy deep orange/copper color with a 1-2 finger dense off white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big balanced sweet/tart apples, caramel, brown sugar, toasted bread, light cinnamon/spice, and herbal/toasted earthiness. Fantastic aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, apples, and light earthy hop/spice notes; with great strength. Taste of big balanced sweet/tart apples, caramel, brown sugar, toasted bread, light cinnamon/spice, and herbal/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate fruit tartness and light herbal/spice bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of sweet/tart apple, caramel, brown sugar, toasted bread, light cinnamon/spice, and herbal/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, apples, and light earthy hop/spice notes; with a great malt/tart/spiciness balance and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from the apple acidity as well. Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, fairly creamy/acidic, and slightly sticky balanced mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with zero warming present after the finish as expected of 4%. Overall this is a fantastic fruit beer. All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, apples, and light earthy hop/spice flavors; and very smooth and refreshing to drink. A highly enjoyable offering.

12 oz bottle Straight outta consin. New Glarus Thumbprint Series Apple Ale is a apple juice (right?) slightly hazy brew with a fine head of white bubbles. Nose is ripe real apple aroma without fake sugar. Taste is pretty much apple. like natural sweet apple, not fake candy apple. Like a gala or Fuji. Body is thinner and a bit lively. What that beverage with the annoying apple beaning people commercials should be.
Labeled as apple ale.... Best new glaraus beer I have had. Not so candy apple or overly sweet.

Very nice apple ale. Like that it isn't overly sweet like a lot of others. Drinkable in moderation

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Where: Neighbor brought back a variety from a trip home to Wisconsin, forever grateful. How: 12 oz bottle, shared at a neighborhood tasting. Appearance: Pours a golden amber transparent beer with a finger head. Aroma: Apple and more apples. Taste: Pretty much all apples, kind of like apple juice. Palate: Lighter side of medium-bodied. Overall: Not as highly rated as some of their others, but a pretty good NG beer.

Bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy copper colour with a small white head. Aroma is apples and caramel. Taste is sweet apples with just a hint of tartness, finishes smooth and sweet again. Some nice caramel and candy notes as well. A really nice fruit beer.
Aroma of apples, taste is more apples, apples, and some mild alcohol. Tasty.

12 oz. bottle from Discount Liquor, Milwaukee, WI. Dark orange pour with a frothy off-white head. Aroma of...apples (what did you expect). Taste is distinctly apple but is perfect, not too tart or sweet, and offers enough carbonation that this is really different from a cider. I did not know what to expect from this but it is exceptional. Great beer!

12 oz. bottle from my Secret Santa, shared at Ale Alpharetta. Pours a clear orange, with a small, bubbly, tan head. The nose is strong red delicious and gala apples, light cinnamon, white sugar, and some light caramel. Very fruity and sweet, with a light acidic tartness. Medium body, crisp, acidic, and clean through the finish. This is a very forward apple beer, but very tasty. This is what a fruit beer ought to be!

Pours hazy honey-golden with a thin eggshell head. Aroma is more like "soft" apple cider, but still tempts. Apple flavor is more cider than ever, but more like alcohol-bearing cider. Mouthfeel is form and smooth with some good fizz. Let this apple tempt you!

From notes. Enjoyed at the Great Taste of the Midwest on August 08. Pour is an apple juice copper. There is a small frothy white head and no lace. The aroma is apple skins and cigarette smoke. There is a little caramel malt in there, and maybe some apple skins, but for the more part, its pretty disappointing. The flavor is, again, apple juice and light apple skins. Its basic, but really good. I am liking the flavor. The mouth feel is a bit light and decently carbonated. It remains crisp in the finish. The aftertaste is lingering apple skins, and a little sweet apple. Pretty good.
Spilled aroma taste of apples and hint cider character with some light malts, very well balanced and crisp apple tart finish.

Pours a very clean, copper color with a low off-white head that fades down fast. Aroma has the smell of fresh smashed apples on the lawn with just a tad bit of yeasty presence. Flavor is phenomenal with notes of fresh apples, lots of residual sweetness and just a touch of tartness at the finish. The carbonation is what really makes this great-sharp and very fine with a pretty modest amount. This really makes the beer pop in your mouth and keeps it from feeling oil due to the high amount of sugars. Overall I wish I grabbed a few more bottles of this. New Glarus could probably sell the apple cider/juice base without it being fermented and make a killing each fall. Great brew!!

Pours clear copper orange with a small fizzy white head. Head retention is ok. AROMA: spice, apple cider, earthy, sweet, slight molasses, light malt, hint of bitterness and slightly tart. TASTE: apple cider, spice, crisp, nutty, light ginger, sweet, slighly tart, malt and light earthy bitterness. AFTER TASTE, tart apple, spice and earthy with a crisp clean finish and a spice warmth in the chest.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2015 Sample at Great Taste of the Midwest. Aroma is funk, apple, caramel, rind. Appearance is apple juice, off white head. Taste is sweet apples, rind, not much. Mouthfeel is light, crisp, not horrible. Overall, its good but not great.

bottle to snifter and I was not disappointed with this new glarus offering. the fresh smell of apple and wheat. the flavor exploded in apple deliciousness how could you go wrong with this. cant drink a lot of them but what you can drink is so good and bright and crisp and so drinkable. love it.

OK so Ive ticked this but havent rated it. But it deserves a rate because it is so good. More of a beer than a cider, New Glarus is king of fruit beers...I dont think any other brewer really comes close. This is just a treat. World class, in fact. Its like apple pie in a bottle with a kick.
Awesome copper color and clear. Aroma of fresh apples. Flavor of tart green apples with a champagne like fresh apple cider finish, with some mild malts rounding it out.

Poured into a pint. Copper apple juice like color. Same aroma, fresh pressed apples. Perfect apple flavor. Not too much like a beer and not too much like and overly sweet cider. Low carbonation fits the bill.

Outstanding apple ale. Juicy apples dominate the aroma and the sharp, snappy finish, yet in between is the sweetness of the wheat and full body of the brown ale -- very different and welcomed in a fruit beer. Enjoyed from an October 2014 bottle (still great after nine months in the beer fridge).
Bottle. Pours a very hazy copper. Aroma is apple cider, smells sweet. Moderately sweet; tastes of apples.
Pours an amber color with minimal head. Flavor is crisp and refreshing, tart apple, well balanced. Overall a fantastic apple ale.

12 oz bottle. From a trade with GT2. Thanks a lot!
Slightly cloudy copper colour with a small off-white head. 
Apples, strawberries, sweetness, mild sourness, toffee and malt in the aroma. 
The flavour is strawberries, sweetness, apples, fermented strawberries and some raisins. Quite complex but not necessarily all great. Still enjoyable and interesting brew.

New Glarus Apple Ale has a thin, white head, a semi-clear, amber appearance, no bubbles and almost no lacing left behind. The aroma is of strong, sweet & sour apple aroma, caramel, and candied malt. Taste is of those elements with citrus and cream cheese. Mouthfeel is light to medium, and New Glarus Apple Ale finishes tart and drinkable. RJT
Orange clear pour from 12oz bottle at home. Super applely. Taste and aroma. Juicy and super pound able. Great beer

Bottle. Pours a bubbly copper with medium beige head that quickly disappears. Nose is enticing - a big aroma of freshly sliced apples dominates, also caramel notes, some bready yeast. Flavor and palate are absolutely superb - such a rich full medley of tart-sweet apple flavors that I feel the salivation in the sides of my cheeks begin as it crosses my tongue - really, that good. The density and flavors of the apple sugars are complex - some like golden raisins, some like sweet reisling grapes, some deeper notes of candied apple and roasted apple pie filling - an onrush of sweetness that is punctuated by a final mildly tannic note of subdued tartness. Blissful.
12oz bottle pours a brown color with a bit of head. Wonderful Apple aroma. Nice sweet Apple flavor balanced against the malt.

Copper pour with a fast disappearing head. Huge fresh apple aroma. Fairly sweet taste, Apple (naturally) also a jam-like sweetness that most New Glarus fruit beers seem to have. Slightly tart and acidic. Medium body. Makes a good replacement for apple cider. Id pair it with Pork Tenderloin myself.

Bottle shared by rosskyle. The hit of apple is intense upon bottle opening. Maybe a little spice like clove or cinnamon but its muted. Appearance is amber color reminiscent of a darker apple juice. Head quickly disappears. Taste is super sweet and very heavy on apple which I guess was expected. Not much of a beer feeling from this one but it does taste good. No real tartness or sour coming through. Very easy to drink but definitely more sweet juice than ale. Thin mouthfeel. I will probably only try this once but not as terrible as you would think.
Awesome big apple aroma. Liked the little darker yoe if apple sour. That way was not just apple cider, had some good body to it as well. Apple shoots through whole experience. Great brew.

Bottle at a tasting thanks to Casey. Pours a very hazy brownish yellow with a slight head. Aroma is toffee apples caramel with some cinnamon. Flavor follows. Tastes like a fresh baked apple pie. Bottle was aged at least three years. Super nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The aroma was quite muted, with maybe a hint of sweetness and a little woodiness, but not unlike the floor of a bar after it has been beer-soaked. The first impressions upon tasting was of the palate--dense, rich syrupy, though not sickly sweet. Apple comes out at the front, with a little twang but mostly low sourness in the finish. Easy drinking, sweet. Bottle.
Это пиво вкусное. я, конечно, рекомен& его всем, что любит хорошую Craft пива!

bottle. Deep amber with one finger head. Big apple, spice and some light malt. I had very high hopes for this, and while its very tasty, Im not blown away. That said, its a very flavorful, well made beer.
Pours unclear blonde, ok white head. Smell is pure apples, funky, bit sweet. Taste is bit bitter, full, narural tasting applejuice. No real beercharactereft.

Bottle, thanks to one of my co-workers. Poured a slightly cloudy light copper yellow color with a small white head. Aroma was wonderful. Like fresh sqeezed apples, some light sweetness even comes off this one - it reminds me of quality cider. The flavor was delicious. It was like a very juicy apple juice, very fresh. Very mild caramel notes. Incredibly easy to drink, the alcohol is there, but it doesnt get in the way, clearly.

Look: pours like a dark apple cider. Very clear. White head with a yellow edge.
Smell: Apple cider. Slight vinegar taste. Cinnamon. Nutmeg. Spiced cider. Heavy sweet apples. 
Taste: Apple cider. Very sweet. Slight dryness. Slight vinegar taste. Apple pie filling.
Feel: very dry. Medium carbonation. 
Overall: great beer. Nice sweet Apple flavor. 
First drank: home 1/2/15
Super delicious. You can taste the ale part in this, but its mostly tart apple, but not like a hard cider. Very unique and tasty. Well done.
New Glarus is the king of fruit beers and this is no different. The apples define the beer, but its not a cider. Bready base soaks through and the sweetness is understated.

Bottle split on the hotel patio, SD, big thanks to GT2 for gifting me this number 14/11/14.
Rich amber/chestnut brown with a light beige covering.
Nose is big on apple pulp, straw, light caramel, woody must, more apple juice.
Taste comprises sweet apple juice, light pear and prune backnotes, caramelised brown sugar, sweet licks.
Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, sweet licks in the close.
Ok for style but a little too sweet for me overall - full on apple orchard attack!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
This beer is awesome! Amazing aroma, awesome apple taste. Hints of the base beer soak thru and add to the complex and rounded experience. Do not pass this up. Crisp, clean, and delicious 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft. Reddish-cooper color. Apple aroma. Strong apple flavors. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Drank from bottle while freezing ass in Lake Placid NY. aroma is strong apples and sweetness. Actually get a lot of strawberry esters, interesting. Taste is sweet, apples and more strawberries. Maybe my brain is wired wrong... Decent fruit beer, but too sweet for me.

Bottle to half-pint glass (shared with the Mrs; thanks arminjewell). Looks good;a fairly transparent orange with foamy light caramel head. Smells of apples and mild related spices. Tastes like it smells with a medium-bodied mouthfeel. A solid fruit beer.

October 14, 2014. Bottle at home. Clear amber with a small white head. Aroma is sweet and tart apple juice, caramel, light spicy and some lactic notes. Taste is medium sweet caramel and apples, medium tart green apples. Medium smooth bodied, soft carbonation.
At tall Matts house with Matt, Matt, garrett, and respective chicks. Pours light orange. fruity semi sweet, Apple, some cheery notes, frosting.

A spare head with spare lacing. Pours an amber color. Aromas of orange peel, bubble gum, and lots of fruit (apple, pear, peach, and cherry). Pure bliss from an aroma standpoint (yes, I like fruit beers). Definite fruit bouquet, in an AWESOME beer.
Bottle from brewer. Clean amber red. Tan head. Nose and taste are apple juice. Buttery and flavorful. Fresh. Nothing artificial.

A clear copper pour. This aroma is confounding, with a blending of gorgeous tart apple character and buttery, toffee malts that are persistently candy-like and cloying; this can reach the level of butterscotch schnapps or caramel coated green apple. This issue is cast aside in the brilliantly textured flavor, which offers a pure, tantalizing apple flavor unsullied by extra sugars or weird off colors. Moments of brown sugar, caramelized pear, and caramel can be perceived, all within the wide spectrum of the apple flavor.
Mildly syrupy but always returning to crisp and drinkable, as is standard; juice box finish.

Pours a glowing copper color with with a half finger of gaseous bubbles that fizzle out quickly. Nose is apple, pure soft sweet apple flesh with a hint of earthy must. Palate is softly carbonated with sweet apple notes that are layered with hints of cinnamon and applesauce with a lingering tannin to help clean up the sweetness on the finish.
Aroma is apples/baked apple pie, fruit and a good hint of funk. The flavor is apple/apple juice/baked apple pie, fruit, malts and a mix of tart, funk and mild sweetness in the finish.
Apple cider aroma from the clear amber body and white head. Refreshing apple taste and clean finish.
bottle into glass shared with pals, this shits pretty much exactly like apple cider, I taste no alcohol,, but its delicious

"if your into apples, this is your ticket. New Glarus continues to prove their forte is in the fruit beers. many juice like qualities, but a deeper flavor abides here. clean as can be, crisp and refreshingly sweet and tart. i dont know how youd make an apple ale better. would be a perfect drink on a crisp autumn day."

Pours a clear dark Amber with a thin head off white head that settles to an oily film and leaves decent lacing. Aroma of apples, butterscotch and short bread. Taste is initially sweet with Granny Smith apples, apple cider, caramel, a hint of tartness and some toasted grain. Mouthfeel is somewhat fizzy with a light/medium body and high carbonation. Very drinkable and simple but nuanced flavors that never become too cloying.

Bottle from unknown via Dan S. Pours a slightly hazy amber, nose redolent of fresh apples, some lacto notes. Body medium lively with a crisp and surprisingly bitter finish, relatively speaking. Damn fine.
golden, clear, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly sour, light body, slick feel, average carbonation,
Has a wonderful green apple and apple cider aroma. Taste is a mix of sweet and tart apples with a very light sour note. Medium but sharp soda like carbonation thats a bit fizzy.
Decent beer, much less sweet than the crappy cider we get around here but still over sweet for my taste. Quite well done though, the flavor is authentic and the aroma is quite nice.

Bottle courtesy of GT2. Pours hazy brownish golden (actually pretty much apple must coloured) with a very small fizzy offwhite head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is fruity and slightly malty with graham crackers, caramel, ripe apples, cinnamon, hay and lemon peal. Taste is tiny sweet, tiny sour, fruity and slightly malty with graham crackers, apple must, cinnamon, nutmeg, moist soil, orange zest and lemon zest. Mouthfeel is crisp, sparkling, slightly tart and light bodied. Finish is tiny sour and fruity with graham crackers, smashed red apples, minerals, hay, orange zest and lemon zest. Aggressive sparkling carbonation, low sweetness, suiting tartness and tons of apple fruitiness makes up for a great fruit beer experience.
Dark copper. Lively pour, thick foamy head. Smells like apples. Tastes like a sweet cider, but with a slight malt build. Incredibly easy to drink. Thanks Erin.
Bottle thanks to respertftw. Smells just like apple cider. Tastes the same with cinnamon. Really good.
(Backlog) Bottle of fantasy tasting at Pauls. Brown copper pour with tan head. Apple pie aromas, spice, light apple tartness. Flavors of apple, sweet tones, spice, tart fruit; almost cider like.

Golden orange in color... Aroma of fresh apple cider... Flavor is apple juice, cider, light acidity on finish... Hardly beer, but enjoyable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This was like a great apple pie in a beer bottle. Sweet and appley. I can dig it.
im confused-how is this just not cider? i liked this but it was way too sweet for me.

Nose of apple, clear amber pour. Palate is a touch thin. Flavour is all apple but a touch sweet for my liking. Love this brewery but maybe my least fav of their offerings. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle shared by JohnGonk. Pours a hazy burnt orange color with a finger of fizzy white head. Aroma and flavor were much the same. Lots of sweet and tart apples, and light bready malts. Absolutely delicious and crushable! Damn New Glarus knows how to kill it with their fruit beers!!

Bottle, via trade with northropfrye-- thanks! Deep bronze body, average white head. Sweet spicy apple aroma and flavour, bready malts, dry and slightly tart finish. Excellent balance, densely flavoured, delicious!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
12.05.2014, 0,35l bottle @ home, courtesy of RobertDale:
Nice creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is sweet fruity, sweet apples, caramel malts, sugar, hay, raisins, hints of red berries. Taste is sweet slightly sour-ish fruity, sweet fresh apples, soda powder, red berries, caramel malts, raisins, cinnamon, hay, grass. Little bitterness, fresh light acidic fruity mouthfeel. Very nice and easy drinking.
Bottle pours creamy amber with low head, aroma is big sweet apples, taste is standard NG fruit beer flavor with mild sweet
bottle from NG. Poured clear amber with thin head. Aroma of straight apple juice. Med high carb thin bod. Taste of tart apples with minor beer quality anf off finish.
A light clear golden appearance. Apple, apple, and more apple on the nose. Apple on the palate, but not overly sweet. Just enough hops to let you know your drinking an ale.

Pours a clear amber brown with bubbly tan head that settles pretty quickly into a medium tan collar. Aroma is of warm apple cider: brown sugar, cinnamon, some faint clove. Taste is wonderfully the same; apple, sweet caramel and some spice. Fairly carbonated and medium body. Another amazing beer from New Glarus!

[Tap] Darker golden color with a small but dense white head. Apple is very pronounced in the nose. Lighter wheat malt and straw also make an appearance. Taste is of apples, cinnamon, brown sugar and some caramel. Crisp, clean and balanced. Tasting notes from 2012.

Red-orange-gold, clear, almost no head. Very appley, sweet nose. Crisp slight bitterness, predominantly sweet. Tailing bit of sourness. Effervescent, quite carbonated, a little acidic. Finishes a little drier than it starts. Quite light body. Not terribly complex, pretty mild, but enjoyable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tasty. Apple juice look thin white head. Cider aroma. Sweet ripe apples, mix of apple juice and cider. Still tasty. Thin body light carbonation.
Clear, golden amber color, off-white head. Musty aroma of apple, dough, and bread malt. A nice blend of tart and sweet flavors. Lively and crisp, very light in body, and a clean finish.

12oz bottle. Semi-dark clear amber with a nice tan head that eventually disappears. Very fresh, semi-tangy apple aroma, light, refreshing, slightly sweet, nice carbonation that allows the apples to dance on the palate, slightly tangy on the finish. Very tasty.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2016 Shared 12 oz., cellared bottle, poured to flight samplers showing a hazed, brownish amber color, with a light layer of off white foam, and minimal lacing. The nose was light grain, caramel sweetness, ripe apple, with a touch of spice. Pleasant, thought its prime had passed, but was surprised to find taste that was tart & crisp, with cidery perkiness, and lightly syrupy, but complementary sweetness. A nice treat! Thanks, Mark! Liked the fresh/draft version at HopCat-Madison, WI. even better. Tulip-like snifter served, with good clarity to the brownish amber color, with off white head foam, and dots & dashes of short lived lacing. With slight toast as the light grain note, apple skins, sweet yet tart, and much livelier carbonation. +.2

Deep Orange, with a tint of rose. Aroma is Apple jolly rancher all day, sweet hard candy. Taste quite dry throughout, with a green apple tang and just a little stickiness in the finish. Not too bad, straightforward all in all. Serendipity is the gold standard for fruit beers from NG...
Pours amber with white head from 12oz bottle. Smells of apple. Tastes like apple. Not to tart...good stuff
Copper color. Aroma of apple juice. Taste is granny smith apples. Bit of sweetness and tartness. This is basically a cider. I guess it doesnt have as much forced sugar. Otherwise cider.

Big thanks to tectactoe. Nice golden color. A fresh crisp apple scent. Fantastic taste. Like youre swimming through an apple pie. Very drinkable and just all around good. One of the best Ive had from the brewery.

Bottle: Thanks to Michael for sending me a bottle of the "Unplugged" version, & thanks to Ryan for picking me up a couple 4-packs of the Thumbprint on his recent excursion to Wisconsin. Review based on Thumbprint bottle, fresh.

Muddled brown-ish bronze & copper, a slightly off-white head lasts for a few minutes on top; no lacing. Total apple pie, apple spice, & apple cider mixture in the aroma. Sweet apples, mildly tart & raw, skins & flesh with hints of graham cracker, butter, cinnamon, much like an apple pie. Some sharp, acidic apple skin notes in the back-end give a mild cider-like vibe, too. Warmth brings out the slightest hint of port, too. Taste has elements of apple cider, apple juice, & straight up apple pie. Mushed apple tartness, sweet red apples, mild cinnamon, & toasted bread crust malt. Slightly astringent tartness with a dry, acidic cider overtone, hitting the tongue sharply. Lovely, crisp finish with brown sugar, apple pie mush, & very faint spice. An apple ale if there ever was one. New Glarus sure knows how to rock a fruit beer. I love apples & apple flavored things, so this is total wheelhouse for me. Pure apple pie goodness.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2014 Bottle thanks to cbfobes. Pours a clear copper yellow with a slight white head. Aroma of sweet over ripe apples. Tastes sweet like apple juice with a slight bread quality to it. Very sticky mouth feel. Super tasty and refreshing.

Bottle (several) from 2011/2012. (2013 is cloyingly sweet and not like the last few years). Pours a light golden yellow with light to medium head. Aroma is apple cider with faint malt notes. Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a tulip.

Apple Ale looks like apple cider with a more robust head.  It is a caramel or dark golden orange color with a hazy effervescence.  The cap on top froths up suitably, eventually leaving a few wisps of a cap and a ring around the edge of the glass.

Tons of red apple notes in the aroma.  It smells sweet and again reminds me of apple cider.  There is a bit of a tart acidity that enters my nose as well.

As any Wisconsin beer lover knows, New Glarus Thumbprint Series (formally known as Unplugged) are never guaranteed to appear again. But, Apple Ale is one of those brews that do keep showing up at the end of each year. In 2012 it was released a little later than the normal October release to accommodate the presence of Enigma already on store shelves. Apple Ale is one of the Thumbprint beers that always seem to be very plentiful, so be sure to pick yours up before its gone. 
It pours a semi-cloudy amber orange color with only a slight white head. The scent is fairly simple with that traditional ale scent mixed with sweet apples. While it does have a sweet apple aroma, it is still not as strong as hard ciders. Very inviting, like an adult juice box just waiting to be drank.
Yum! The sweet tartness of the apples attacks your taste buds right away. This years brew is perhaps a little better than I remember the previous years being. The texture is smooth and generously filling as it delivers fantastic blend of ale with apples. If you like hard ciders and want to make a step up to something a little tastier and filling, this is a good place to start. Sorry folks, but its not gluten free though. It finishes very clean with mild tartness. 
 This is one of beers that can take you back to your childhood as this is essentially a big kids version of apple juice. It makes for a great complimentary beverage for fall harvest meals before it becomes time for porters and stouts with winter approaching. Delicious tasting, well made, what else could you ask for? Oh, yeah thats right More please!

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle thanks to cbfobes. Thanks! Pours a somewhat hazy copper with a thick, velvety head of white foam. The aroma is like baked apples with cinnamon. It smells great! Its got just the right amount of sweetness and spices to remind me of apple pie. This is one great beer, for sure.

Very tasty apple ale.  Its definitely not a cider and is a beer.   Aroma hits you the second the bottle opens.  Apples, apples, apples.  Really fresh.  Pours a pretty cloudy golden orange with a fluffy head that quickly dissipates, giving way to some modest lacing.  Its light to medium bodied and a bit oily in the mouth, but not excessively so. Taste is tart apples and some very light spicing.  Its a beer and tastes like a beer.  Not a cider.  Very good and reminds you of fall.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2013 Pours a clear light orange, lots of carbonation. Small creamy fizzy white head.  Apple pie. Just delicious. Good balance of sweet, sour, and tart. Not nearly as sweet as apple cider, or like cider in any other way..its still beer. The overall apple character is just so nice. I keep going back to apple pastry-like character. New Glarus does this really well.

Bottle to Odonata straight sided "tulip". Fresh pressed apple cider color in the glass with a short lived white head.  Aroma is fresh apple juice and the fragrance of an empty glass of bourbon whiskey after the ice has melted down.   Apple juice, topsoil, and cinnamon flavors fill the mouth.  Not too sweet and more juice like than a hard apple cider.  Very light bodied.  Tasting very nice on a November evening.
Aroma of fresh apple cider.  Copper colored with some cloudiness.  Nice tangy fizziness on the palate.   Very fresh and crisp tasting.

12 oz. bottle served in a Duvel Green tulip.

A: Pours a solid amber color with a one finger height of white head forming on the pour. It recedes to a thin collar.

S: Green sour apple jolly ranchers are big on the nose. There is a sold malt undertone to it with some red apple sweetness.

T: A touch of jolly rancher up front, but it quickly gives way to a nice, bright red apple flesh with just a smidgen of raw apple skin. The finish is slightly mealy like an apple core thats been set out exposed to the air too long, but not in a bad way. The malt base gives it a touch of sweetness and a little heft to the body.

M: Medium to light bodied with a nice medium high carbonation level. The finish is malty and sweet.

O: Im glad the base brown ale malts still have some say in the taste and it doesnt come off as a cider. A nicely put together beer with the main focus being the apples. Definitely a nice fall treat.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-03-2012
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. This is a green apple treat. A bit on the sweet side, but the tartness helps to balance this beer. Very enjoyable.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a hazy copper orange with next to no head. Aroma of subtle clean fresh apples, some creaminess - possibly vanilla, also some apricot and caramelised sugar. Flavour is as expected from the aroma, delicately sweet, crisp, refreshing, nothing offensive. Similar to a pleasant cider. Decent session beer.

12 oz. bottle, sent from FullObs (thanks Brett), pours a hazy copper / bronze with a small white head. Aroma of green apples that pretty much dominate, with a bit of candied sugar sweetness. Flavour reminds me more of an apple cider, with fresh green apples and a bit of sweetness - well-balanced. No hint of the wheat or brown ale qualities. Solid flavour profile for being < 4%, but the whole thing feels a bit whimsical, especially compared to Raspberry Tart and Wisconsin Red. Nevertheless, solid refreshing light fruit beer.
Bottle. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruiy fresh apple aroma. Sweetish fruity apple flavor. Has a sweetish fruity apple finish.

Apple juice color.  White head that recedes quickly.  Smells like fresh apple juice.  Taste just like sweet, crisp, awesome apple juice.  This is like a sweet, carbonated hard cider.  I could drink this all day!

Bottle from Brookfield Discount. Pours very clear coppery orange - apple juice colored - with a slight white head. Very little lacing. Aroma has apples ... and apples. Perhaps some caramel.  Caramel apples? A touch of maltiness but it is faint and actually I get less of it as I get through the glass. Taste is of sweet apples, nice and fresh, with some candied sugar and perhaps some caramel. It is sweeter than most ciders. Finishes light and sweet, and not very long. Quite tasty. More cider or low carbonated wine cooler than beerish.
bottle. pours duhh apple juice color with a crispy white head very bubbly. aroma is apple and apple. tatse is delicious like a hard cider but with more sweet and just plain better

Bottle. The aroma is amazing. It hits you as soon as you open the bottle. The taste is like apple cider/juice in a fantastic way. Different, but good stuff. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle from a trade with Atom: Clear orange copper color with a nice fluffy head.  Aromas of tart apples and caramel, some breadyness, kind of reminds me of apple pie. I started to get the aroma as soon as I poured it.  Taste of sweet caramel malts with a tart apple fruityness. The taste is very natural and not artificial. Dry finish. Great full mouth feel without being heavy I could drink a lot of the beer and still enjoy.  I hope to get more someday.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2014 Bottle as shown. Pours a clear gold with paperthin white head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is a strong apple and cherry. Thin mouthfeel with a sweet apple and tart finish. Easy to drink a very impressive Fruit beer from New Glarus.

This is my first beer by NG.  This beer is in a class of its own when it comes to fruit beers.  Blows away the stuff I was drinking in Belgium...seriously.  Fruit beers usually have some fruit with a crazy alcohol taste and some other odd tastes.  Not here.  This beer is all fruit and it is awesome!!!  Completely undetectable alcohol and HUGE apple taste.  I swear this tastes like awesome carbonated apple jiuce.  Really really nice beer!!
Color of apple juice with the same kind of flat head. Strong aroma of apple jolly ranchers. Flavor is lightt pale ale, wheat, pale malt, and lots of sweet apple. Very easy drinking, sweet. Delicious.
Pours gold with little lacing. Heavy apple an apple cider aroma. Noted of cinomin. Literally no bitterness or signs of hops.

Poured into my bruery tulip, copper in color with no head. Aroma of apple cider, almost an apple pie aroma. Taste follows the nose, sweet, tart apples with some malts in the back. Smooth and hides alcohol well. Tasty and different, a great change of pace, very good, if not great!
Bottle pours a gold white head smells and tastes very strong apple. Pretty much tasted like apple juice and thats bout it. Very nice smell and taste though fresh.

Thanks to GT2 ! . Pours clear amber with a tiny white head. Aroma is baked apples, apple pie, gentle sugary, apple juice, ripe plums, butter and a little hint of cinnamon. Taste is fresh apple juice, apple vinegar, sweet cider, weak butter and some ripe plums. Very one sided but indeed good!

Bottel courtesy of GT2, thanks! Pours clear golden, with a small white head, Aroma: Baked apples, cinnamon, apple pie, æblemost, artisanal apple juice, brown sugar, pie crust, deep complex apple aroma, but besides som some caramel malts thats all you get in the aroma. Not that it\s a bad thing, smells lovely! Taste: Applejuice, sweetsweet apples, cider, light acidic fruityness, some caramel, aplle cider vinegar, carbonated apple juice, one dimensional, but very tasty!

Bottle courtesy of GT2. Copper pour, quickly dissipating head. Aroma is full of apples - much like baked apples, that really concentrated sweet apple aroma, a nice hint of cinnamon and pie crust - bit of a one trick horse, but it's a lovely aroma anyway. Aroma is a bit similar to a nice late harest white wine. Taste is very sweet and apple forward - almost like apple juice. Apple notes melts in well with the malt sweetness. A small refreshing tartness on the back of the palate, which suites it well. Very sweet, but the apple taste makes it become refreshing and not close to cloying. Would love more of this!!

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2016 Refrigerated bottle from Joepeesie, on tap, and growler poured into a white wine glass.  Pours clear deep golden (copper hues) with small white head that dissipates quickly.  Some small bubble lacing, low carbonation, smooth texture, and wonderful apple aroma.  Taste is complex tart fairly rich apple.  This is one of the easiest beers to drink and  best apple beverage I have ever had.  Joe thanks for sending me this, wonderful.
Delicious like all the fruit beers from NG.  Really heavy sweet/tart green apple aroma and flavor accented by light notes of wheat and cracker.  If you like apples find this.

Originally reviewed: 2/25/11. The pour yields a dark copper color that resembles fresh cider. Whod have thought? Small head; light lace. The nose is rich with fresh-crushed apples, honeysuckle, damp wood, and faint earthy tones. 

Good crisp body that is sharp and clean. Fresh apples all over the flavor. Mild sour notes, but this is much sweeter than expected. Honey-kissed bread noted as well. Slight dry note on the finish, but it is fleeting. This may very well be the most drinkable fruit beer I have ever had. I think I like this better than their RT or BR. I loved this.
Another great fruit beer from new Glarus, nose of apple jolly ranchers, taste is of great tart green apples. I really like this brewery.
Sweet, slightly tart apples with a bready, malty finish. Theres a bit of apple candy in there but not cloyingly sweet. Interesting finish..
Bottle with James, Andrew, and Maggi. smells just like a sour apple candy. Taste is very apple juice like with some slight nuttiness. really easy to drink.
Bottle with Dallas, Maggi, and James.   Super vivid aroma.. Like apple caramel lolly pops.  Taste is more mellow than aroma would suggest.. Delicious red apple and champagne yeast.

Bottle from a trade with mikem409, poured into a tulip.  Clear, golden with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is of apples, apple candy, caramel.  Taste is more apples, very very sweet, with just a little tartness.  Finish is sweet, with some grain coming through at the very end.  Medium bodied, sticky/syrupy, soft carbonation.  Somehow refreshing.  My only major complaint is that I would have liked some more tartness, especially on the finish.  Overall its like an apple soda, and I mean that in a good way.

Bottle thanks to GT2. Nose is delicious candy, but dont think anyone can make apple candy that tastes this good. Dreams come true. If you were to replicate the nectar of the gods that they drank on Mount Olympus, it would taste exactly like this

Light amber colour, white head. Aroma of apples, apple cores, apple pie. Sweet flavour, sweet apple, pommeau, malts and a hint of wood. Slightly cloying, finish pronounced apple, light wood, quite sweet. Nice if you like apple pie (and lets be honest, who doesnt)
(From 35,5 cL bottle, unplugged series, shared @ ZZT3, Oirschot. Bottle from trade with atxdelivery, thanx friend!)

Via trade with Mashmaster.  The aroma is fruity esters, bready, brown sugar.  The appearance is a relatively clear copper color, white head.  The flavor is baked apples, brown sugar, bread.  The finish is sweet, almost no hop bittering.  Medium in body, a little thick actually.  Syrupy mouthfeel.  Pretty good.  Thanks, Tom.

355ml bottle @ ZZT III, courtesy of Martinus. Clear orange-golden color, small white head that disappears quickly. Smells fruity, a lot of apple indeed. Taste apple, sweetness, cinnamon and some hints of wood. Lightly sticky texture, low body, low carbo.

Smells like apple, caramel, round sweetness, apple pie. Tastes apple, wood, maybe even some whisky, sweet, cinnamon. Thick palate, good carbo. Nice beer.

This beer is a mental giant. The aroma is hands down the best apple aroma Ive ever experienced.  Pure, crisp apple with fresh peel. Mouthfeel is lightly syrupy but thinner than the Belgian red or raspberry tart.

the best apple ale Ive had with a wonderful palette and taste.  It is very fresh and made of Wisconsin, fresh apples.  It has a pleasing sparkling apple aroma and tastes very from the tree fresh and ripe and not overbearing to the underlying ale flavor.
One of the top beers Ive drank in my time. This is not cider, its beer. And it doesnt get any better than drinking this...omg apple pie and thanksgiving came early.

Poured a beautiful golden yellow, with a very small head that quickly dissipated. It smells like a caramel apple sucker in liquid form. The carbonation in this beer is crazy, champagne-like with bubbles that dont seem to stop. Tastes just like sparkling cider, crisp, refreshing, but with a very full body. This is a very different beer, almost like cider, but not exactly. I am very glad I got my hands on this brew.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2012 Pours clear honey light copper in color with a decent off white head. The incredible aroma of fresh crisp apples, straight up apple jolly rancher with sweet and light tart notes. These characteristics translate directly to the flavor, nice crisp lightly zesty apple with more sweet than tart notes, so juicy and delicious!

Puissant parfum naturel de pomme mcintosh. En bouche cest juteux avec un léger remous deffervescence. Plus près du moût de pomme que de la bière, le grain et lalcool sont imperceptibles. Bien fignolé avec une buvabilité morbide.

Bottle, pours brown-hinted gold. Good, lively head that quickly dissipates to almost nothing. Nose is fresh apples, a bit of sour apple Jolly Rancher as well. Just apple apple apple. Taste follows suit: crisp, fresh apples, hints of cider. Straightforward, wonderful.
Bottle at a recent tasting...  Poured deep, hazy amber with a faint, bubbly head.  Like candied apple pie.  Strong candied sweetness and a slight tart crispness.

12oz bottle. Fairly clear gold pour.  Not much head and no lacing or retention.  Nose is apple.  Taste is apple.  Fairly similar to sparkling cider but not as sweet.  Crisp and refreshing.  I really like this for what it is.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The body is a nice, clean copper... full of bubbles and a sudsy white head. Smells a little grassy and spicy with an enveloping fresh apple scent. The taste is crisp apple with some mellow cereal undertones. I like the finish the most, it is dry with cinnamon and a mouthful of green apples at the end.

Tasted on 2/12/12 from a 12oz bottle given to me by CurtisMcArthur, big thanks.  Pours clear copper with an average off-white head that slowly recedes to thin lace.  The nose is somewhat sweet freshly squeezed apple juice with some caramel malt and a touch of baking spices.  The flavor is the same lightly sweet apple juice, hint of caramel, and the baking spices a little more prevalent.  The body is light, but still a bit sticky, with more lively than average carbonation and a long spiced apple finish.
UPDATED: FEB 4, 2012 Nice apple nose.  Light and crisp.  Almost like an apple soda, but not as sweet.  Moderately tart.

Ar: Lots of tart apples, hay, a bit of funk.
Ap: Clear golden-amber - medium off-white head with good retention, nice ring of lacing.
T: Very tart apple, but sweetness mellows the tartness - apple juice and some light caramel - a little bit of vanilla - low bitterness with a long apple-y finish.
P: Medium-light body - creamy and lush - finish is medium-dry.
O: This apples embodied - malt, caramel, and vanilla give it some distinctiveness from a cider - delicious and fun!

Clear golden amber with a white head that fades quickly and leaves minimal lacing... Aroma is of creamy apple cider fairly spicy notes of vanilla green apple... Flavor follows suit, lightly creamy faint touch of vanilla and apples light spice not very sweet, but certainly doesnt emphasize the tartness of the apple... Light body fairly easy drinking but a little brash in the throat...

Deliciously crisp beer.  Pour caramel with amber highlights. Aroma is pure apple, delicately balanced with sweet brown sugar and toffee notes to cut the acidity, lending a certain degree of roundness to the nose after a sharp beginning. Flavor finds a similar balance between the tangy tartness of apple and drinkability of a session beer, with tart apple at the forefront, seemlessly giving way to a smooth and sweet brown ale.

Pours a clear golden/mild amber color with a thin white head...doesnt look at all like the brown ale base they claim though.  Aroma smells of apple cider.  Flavor is much like an apple cider...great appley noted with some underlying subtle spice...cinnamon.  mouthfeel is very light...lively...finish is dry and appley.  Exactly what the title claims it is!  They should throw this in an oak barrel with brett!

Bottle, pours a bubbly, clear gold body with white head.  Aroma of fresh picked apples and apple juice/cider.  Flavor is similar, although almost candy-like, reminiscent of Jolly Rancher sour apple candy.  Slightly tart near the finish.  A little sticky and syrupy on the palate.  This is okay, but nothing remarkable.

4 oz. pour from 12 oz. bottle, split with friends while watching the bowl games. Thanks, iradog, for sharing. Apple juice aroma noticeable from several feet away. Very powerful, apple cider/juice smell. Pours a clear gold with light bubbling and a small amount of beige head. Apple pie and red apple flavors. Spicy and quite sweet taste. Medium body. Lively and sharp in the palate.  Unique and pleasing if not excellent ale.

Pours a clear gold color with a medium white head.  Aroma of fresh picked red apples.  Taste has a slight tartness along with the dominant apple taste.  Finish is crisp and lingers with the tart apples.  A wonderful beer, a fun drink.

dark gold pour with a medium foamy white head.
aroma is strong apple cider, sour green apple candy
flavour is same, apple cider, some tartness to it. hint of caramel maltiness.
Interesting stuff.

Bottle pours golden with no head.  Aromas are apple, like candy.  Taste is similar, with definite fresh apple taste and not much else.  I really thought this was tasty, but really did not see anything beer like about it.  There was a hint of malt on the finish, but overall, very much like apple juice.  Overall, tasty, but not what I was expecting.

You can definately smell the apple aroma.  It has a nice gold/copper color.  I like this beer because you get that apple juice/cider taste yet it still tastes like beer.  A great selection for these cold months.

Bottle shared by DalzAle. Pours clear gold with a quick little fizzy head. Aroma is pure candy apple treats. Taste is more delicious apple candy with a little faint tartness. Palate is thin fizzy and clean with a dry finish. I could drink these all day or until I get a stomach ach! Very tasty!
12oz bottle pours a clear orange/amber with a small white head. Aroma is of caramel apples and a slight spices. Tastes like apple cider and Christmas potpourri. A bit too sweet for me, but enjoyable.

12oz. Bottle: Got in trade from changeup45; THANKS Garry!  Aroma of funk, apple, slight diacetyl, and spoiled juice.  Poured copper/amber/apple juice in color with a small, white head around the edges only.  Clear.  Lightly sparkling.  Flavor medium sweet.  Tastes of apple juice, funk, and apple cider.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Funk, apple, and apple cider finish is medium sweet.  Really just fermented apple juice.

Bottle from Glouglouburp. Thanks Dany! Pours crystal clear reddish-amber; head is 1-finger thick, off-white, and remarkably short-lived. No lacing either. Nose is remarkable; fresh apples both red delicious and caramelized apples are especially noticeable. Some light yeast and caramel notes here as well, along with the lightest suffestion of cinnamon/spice. Flavours are nicely tart, with the malt base surprisingly intact, beneath layer after layer of tart apples. Almost more of a cider than a beer, but at the same time, this is so pleasant that I cant find anything wrong with that...

Bottle. Clear copper body. Short, off-white head, rapidly diminishing. Strong aroma of apple and butter. Hint of cinnamon, caramel, brown sugar. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly tart. It finishes moderately sweet and lightly to moderately tart. Thin body, slick texture, lively carbonation. Big apple pie aroma, but the flavor is overly buttery, so much so that I couldnt drink much of this. Tasted like apple pie (with spices) with lots and lots of butter melted on it.

Bottle. Clear dark gold pour. Lots of sweet apples (not green!) dominate the aroma, cinnamon spicy character is there too. Very interesting how they integrated the apple aroma to this one. Taste is like apple crumble, lots of apples, cinnamon and something sweet like caramelized brown sugar. Good body for such low ABV, with strong carbonation. Very cool fruit beer.

This beer is surprisingly good. Smells like apples, tastes like apples mixed with beer. Very unusual but comes together wquite nicely. Mouthfeel is a little light but so is the ABV so that makes sense. Of course I could think it tastes like hell because as soon as my wife tried it she said "this is mine, I love it" so my review is fairly abridged and going with her take on it. Guess Ill have to get me (us) some more of this.

Holy cow, this one is amazing.  Bottle at Meridian Pint, courtesy of Whitney, thank you maam!  The aroma was like having a dozen warm apple turnovers shoved up your nose at the same time - but in a god way.  The taste is equally shocking, not too sweet, not too sour.  Tons of fruits plus all the stuff that goes in those apple turnovers, like raisins, very very light and subtle cinnamon, and that gooey stuff that ends up in between all the little chunks of apple.  Ill say it again.  Amazing.

pours clear rose with no head or lacing.  aroma is very sugary with strong apple notes.  taste is sweet and body is syrupy.  theres almost a sour ale quality here but the apple predominates with cranberry in the background.  finish is sweet but light.

Bottle from Mashmaster, thanks. Pours clear cobber with a quick dissapering white foamy head. Aroma is apples, applejuice, caramel malt, Flavor is sweet apples in the beginning, light apple acid, caramel notes. Very intersting brew. Great on an indian summer night as we have in Denmark today.
355ml bottle from jsprime. clear amber with a small white head. huge spiced apple nose. huge apple flavour with the base beer playing a back ground role. another excellent fruit beer from new glarus.
Smells like fresh apple strudel.  Medium sweetness - this is delicious; apples, light spices, pastry crust.  Superb.

Wow, this is alcoholic apple juice without the cider bite.  Poured a golden clear yellow with little head.  Aromas of apples, hint of spice maybe cinnamon.  Flavor is apples, and I only got apples, nothing else, amazing beer and paired well with the Florida heat.
Not usually one for fruit beers, but it seems like New Glarus just cant do wrong!
Bottle, thanx to tkrjukoff. Pours clear golden with a small, off-white head. Complex aroma of cinnamon, ginger and a hint of apple. Sweet taste of ginger and some apple. Fresh.

Thanks to my brother for sharing this bottle. A fruit beer from New Glarus? Yes please.

The beer pours an amber color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the apple pie. I get all of the notes I expect, with some cinnamon, apple and bready notes.

The flavor also doesnt disappoint. I get cinnamon, apple and crust notes. This beer tastes like an apple pie. Awesome. 

Thin to medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. 

There are lots of breweries out there, but I dont think anyone does fruit beers better than our friends from Wisconsin.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Bronze in colour with fairly strong carbonation. Aromas of royal gala apple, vanilla, and faint cooking spice. A nice blend of apple and pale malt flavours going on, with a near perfect balance of sweet and tart. Light bodied and refreshing. Good stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2012 Date: July 19, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Discount Liquor, Waukesha, WI Appearance: Translucent copper and thick white head. Aroma: Apple of course, sweet and tart. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, very smooth, sweet apple start with sour apple finish. Other: Another interesting fruit offering from New Glarus, this was just like an apple cider, which I guess was decent but not necessarily my thing in a beer. 

Re-rate on 11.16.12 via bottle from Brandon.  Upped by taste and overall ratings.

from keenan 12/30/10.

Caramel-y gold color.

Smells like bruised tart and sweet apples mixed with white wine and caramel.

Tastes like that too!.... real apple-y goodness mixed with malty caramel. 

It is clean with no sugary or artificial residues. Interesting approach. 8/3/8/4/17/

(Bottle, thanks tkrjukoff!) Pours clear amber with a small white head. The aroma holds apples (most green, but also a whisper of red), spices like ginger and maybe some clove, light syrup, malt and other subtle fruits. The flavour is light to medium sweet and light acidic. No bitterness. Tones of apples, subtle malt and a touch of spices. The mouthfeel is clean and tiny syrupy with a light to medium carbonation. Tart apple tones lingering. Light to medium bodied.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours clear deep amber with a shortlived bubbly beige head leaving some lace. Aroma is very sweet, apple pie, hints of ginger, caramel and syrup. Flavor is sweet apples, sourish, pungeant, a bit thin body. Finish is sweet spicy and a bit sour apple. Missed hops.

Bottle shared thx to tkrjukoff cons 2011-07-09 Sätila
AR: maple syrup, cinemoon
AP: oily, copper colored body, wee white head
F: thick and oily feeling, maple syrup ( the real stuff, like the Camp) wee tart ess, white pepper corns, a bit watery felling
Bottle, thanks to tkrjukoff. Pale orange color, small white head. Apple aroma, syrupy, kinda sweet. Apple flavor, syrup, ginger and cinnamon notes, a little vinous.

12 ounce bottle. I dont know how he does it, but Dan Carey is an absolute genious when it comes to fruit beers! Pours a golden caramel color with a medium white head. Aromas of apple (of coarse!) and slight malt. Crisp, almost tart apple flavor with just a hint of cinnamon and caramel. I could drink ALOT of this on a hot summer day! Excellent.

Poured from 12oz bottle.  Pours caramel in color, looks and smells like apple cider.  There is little to no head at all on this, but a nice amount of carbonation.  Taste is similar to a dry apple cider.
trade with madvike&hbmason-12oz bottle-pours an off white head and amber color.  Aroma is apple, light malt, spice.  Taste is spiced apple cider.

Aroma: smells like apple juice and autumn leaves, I kid you not, amazing; Appearance: clear caramel, reddish hue on the edges, hold it up to the light to emphasize the red; Taste: absolutely wonderful, and Im not usually one for fruit beers, I think the best thing about it is this: a lot of other apple ciders Ive had add a boatload of cinnamon and currant to the overal flavor, whereas, with this brew, theres none of that, instead, theres just a fresh, unadulterated apple flavor that borders every so slightly on tart, its really, really refreshing, and I would actually recommend drinking it chilled; Palate: slight tart, slight sweet, both linger, extremely easy to down one quickly, just the right amount of carbonation, a lot less bubbly than other beers, but this is right for the overall cider experience; Overall: its incredibly easy to down one of these in no time flat even if you meant to savor every swallow, I wish I could get these year round because Id always have them on stock, highly recommended

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2014 Bottle @ home, courtesy of TheAlum. Fairly clear, dark orange appearance with white head. Quite sweet apple cider, caramel malty nose. Slightly roasty apple, light caramel malty flavor with a dry finish. Interesting beer but Ive had numerous other fruit beers from New Glarus that I find to be far superior. Update: really fun beer to get shitfaced on. Bonus points added.

12oz bottle (courtesy of Headbanger) poured into a Flute at 43°.  Color is a bright clear copper with mild carbonation and a thin tight head.  Aroma of apple cider and raisins.  Its light body has a crisp mouth feel.  Flavor is like apple cider with some clove and oak.  After taste is clean with a lightly sweet apple taste.  Overall its a very good and refreshing brew.

bottle shared by murphym45 - one of the more controversial NG unplugged beers that my palate has experienced. sweet body, light sugar, sparkling cider almost. Caramelized apples, with a sour fruit note. Tasty, but the apple esters are a bit too strong so it winds up tasting almost artificial. A bit more subtly would do the trick here. Cant complain too much though, still delicious.

12oz "Unplugged" bottle.  $2.50 single @ Rays, Wauwautosa. Under the cap, the smell is brown ale and old apple cider. Pour into glass looks like a brown apple cider, with a noisy fizzy head. Taste is mostly apple cider, though the malt does give some backing to it. Pretty full of malt and juice, nicely fizzy, but it doesnt hang together as a great concoction. I like it enough, though.

On tap.Wow, this is the first time Ive come across New Glarus Apple Ale in about 15 years. To find it on tap was a special treat.

Pours a clear pale gold with thin, bubbly head that doesnt add much to the appearance or lacing. Aroma is crisp fresh apples not unlike a cider, only with a stronger malt nose. Flavor is also similar to a hard cider with fresh, soft apple flavors (very much unlike the liquid Apple Jolly Rancher cooked up by Lindeman) but with a bit more filling malt and maybe a small dose of hops to remind you that this is actually beer. Clean, tingly, thirst-quenchingly moist palate with a good sweet red-apple finish. This is a very able thirst-quencher but not nearly as good as I remember it. (I also have to wonder if it would be rated so highly here if it had a label slapped on it from some middling brewery rather than a New Glarus label. Theres a very similar-tasting Belgian apple ale listed here thats rated almost a full point lower... hmm...) Maybe my memory has faded over the years but I remember some 15 years ago when New Glarus was just getting off the ground and you could find the Apple Ale year-round in 750ml bottles seemingly as a companion to the Belgian Red and Raspberry Tart, like the three formed their own miniature "artisan fruit-beer" series. I also remember the original Apple Ale being similarly unfiltered as the Tart and Belgian Red, looking almost like the unfiltered cider you find in gallon-jugs in the grocery store produce section when fall rolls around.. And for that matter, i also remember the original having quality-control issues as it was not uncommon to get a bottle that had turned. Maybe thats why its considerably more filtered than the original version. I wish they could do it the "old" way, but if they cant, this is a reasonable substitute.... but sadly, not as satisfying.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with and courtesy of Vinnie. First off, let me just say, "Holy Shit." This is one of the best session beers I have ever tasted in my entire life. Once popped, this beauty pours an ever so slightly cloudy, yet dominantly clear pumpkin orange with a soft, fluffy white gentle head that rests atop the beer and leaves spotty traces across the surface. After each sip, a wave of tightly bubbled lace rises and then falls, leaving a high-water mark of lacing. Nose is overwhelmingly Fuji  and Granny Smith apple tart mixed with graham cracker pie crust, fresh vanilla ice cream, carmelized honey, doughy yeast, and subtle notes of . Freshly baked, chunky tart apple pie filling and subtly roasty pie crust wash over the tongue, leaving behind notes of vanilla ice cream, cinnamon, and even some slight cherry in the finish. Soft, supple, yet tangy, slightly chewy palate with a spritely, lively body to enrich and enhance the tart apple and vanilla flavors. Finishes crisply, but with just enough juicy apple smoothness to make it perfectly balanced. New Glarus really work wonders with fruit. Try this ale if you are a serious fan of beer.

Bottle. Pours amber with a small bright white head. Aroma is apples, cinnamon, and nutmeg. Flavor is alot of apple. Medium mouthfeel...This is exactly what it sounds like...and apple ale...fruity as hell....but delicious as hell.
This is almost a cider, soft apple flavors, very little carbonation and almost no head. Generally sweet.

This isnt exactly what I was expecting when getting ready to drink this, but it was enjoyable nonetheless.  Pours a pale golden light brown with medium off-white head.  Aroma and taste match with sweet apple, roasted malt, and slightly nutty.  Makes for a refreshing change-of-pace brew.
12oz bottle. Wow!!! This beer is crazy good. The aroma is just like home made apple pie. A lot  of spice in the nose and flavor with hints of cinnamon. Easy to drink and enjoy all day long.

Bottle thanks to Scott. Pours a hazy orange, minimal head and very little lacing. Aromas of cherries, fuji apple cider, nutmeg, vanilla, cherry water ice. Taste is cinnamon spice, puckery skin of apple, cherry pie, bread crust, creamy apple juice finish. Touch of oakiness in the finish. Has a similiar profile to the Enigma plus the addition of ripe apple goodness. Another ridiculous fruit beer from New Glarus. Delicious

This is a back rate from a while ago, but probably one of the best beers I have ever had. Aged for 2 years (2008 bottle), I dont like the fresh ones as much, but they are still great. Tastes more like an apple cider (not a hard cider) than a beer. Aroma is fresh apples, tastes is the same, just fresh and sweet without that fake sugary sweetness. Seriously, just awesome.

Thanks to Masterski for the bottle. Served in a pint glass.

Pours a light copper for with a minimal white head.and just a spot or two of lacing. Thin collar. Nose brings some cinnamon and other spices plus quite a bit of cider character. A bit odd, but I like it.

Flavor brings quite a bit of spools and some sweetness plus some nutmeg and other spices. A bit too sweet. Feel is prickly with a lot of carbonation. Overall, quite a unique beer but I really am enjoying this.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-23-2010
apples, nutmeg, cinnamon. golden look with not to much head.  apples cinnamon, nutmeg, creamy, grapes.  well bodied.
Pours a nice applejuice pour with a little head. Smell is apples and pears. Taste is pure applejuice. Sweet peaches. Overall a really good brew

Pours a golden color like apples juice with a nice white head to it. Smells like apples and yeast. Has  a nice crisp apple taste to it followed by a little yest. Im not into fruit beers at all but I must say this one is pretty good. Just like drinking apple juice.

12 oz. bottle from the Verona Wine Supply, or Shop; I forget the exact name. Im consuming this out of a plastic hotel cup. Fluffy head that recedes to a wispy head. Hazy peach-gold appearance. I see nothing wrong with the way it looks. Wow, this has an amazing sweet apple aroma. It has a subtle sour aroma to it, but it really hits home with the juicy apple aroma. Also, Im getting a slight wheat backing to this. Not terribly nuanced, but still, the fact that the aroma has such a pungent apple aroma makes this beer smell great. This is very smooth, as it just rolls across the tongue. Perfect texture. Flavor is slightly tart apple skins with a cinnamon backing. Touches of wheat and yeast are popping through. New Glarus seems to have a powerful grasp on how to properly brew poignant fruit beers. Cheers.

Bottle from Festival Foods in La Crosse. The beer pours a clear pale amber color with a medium somewhat fizzy off-white head that burns away quickly. Stringy lacing. Apple juice aroma. Medium, dry body with and apple flavor that is more apple juice than apple cider. There is a touch of sweet malt as well. The finish is effervescent and fruity with a very short apple aftertaste. Decent overall.

this brew was amazing.  My gf and I split a bottle and poured into flute style champage glasses.  Smells like an apple orchard on a crisp fall day.  Light amber color, low carbonation, no head.  tastes like light apple, semi sweet, semi dry, no hops detected.  Little malt.  Reminds me more of a lambic or cider.  This is a great after dinner drink or great on its own on a saturday afternoon.  Little alcohol detected. A

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 Aroma: crisp apples, smells sweet like cider, a touch of cereal grains but predominantly strong apple aroma.
Appearance: Brilliantly clear light amber, fizzy white head with slightly below average retention, some spotty lacing.
Flavor: prominent apple flavor, slight sweetness, a touch of light grains.  Not a lot of complexity, but very good.
Palate: medium body, fairly high carbonation, nice crisp finish.
Overall: an excellent, extremely drinkable fruit ale.  Delicious.

Bottle shared by Dogbrick. Pours clear amber with a thin white head. Aroma is straight up apple juice. Crisp apple flavor with a bit of maltiness and a semi-sweet finish. Not much going on beer wise. Not detecting anything in terms of hops and theres no aftertaste to this at all. I enjoy it sure, but dont think I would pick it out as a beer if I wasnt told it was one.
A cleaner, less rotten tasting version of the average cidre. A strong effort.
Sampled at The Stables Beer Lovers anonymous.  A light and  clear pour.  A cidery aroma and flavor.  There are some very light spices and this is much like an apple juice.  It is so easy to drink.
Transparent copper color with a thin foamy head. Basicly a malty cider with high carbonation and a bit of a yeast flavor in the finish.
Very strong smell of apples as well as for the taste. Taste much more like a spiked cider over beer.

12oz bottle scored as an extra in a trade with Tooch.  Pours a transparent, honey copper amber with zero head.  Looks like a New Glarus beer.  Nose is nice, apples, sort of brown oxidized apples, apples on the ground at an orchard, caramel, sweet.  Flavor is apples, apple juice (not cidery), some light malt, some grass.  Light on the palate but crisp.  Refreshing and very approachable from a fruit standpoint.  The wife loved it.

12oz bottle from Tooch4321  thanks Adam.  Pours clear dark gold with a thin white head that faded faster than my attention span during a Hallmark movie.  The nose is fresh apples, spiced apple cider with a faint malt background.  The taste is pretty much the same.   Medium mouthfeel.  Tasty and very cider-like.
Pours deep straw yellow/brown with a nice level of carbonation.  Very nice notes of apples show off the acidic but yet true sweet but yet tart apple finish.

Liquid candy from New Glarus.  Aroma is very subtle and sweet with apple.  Pours a dark, golden carbonated throughout with a thin, fizzy white head.  Taste is like carbonated apple juice, very sweet, and fizzy.  Very light body with a nice sweet finish.  Very easy to drink.  This one gulps down fast and the taste is delicious.  Good job NG

The smell and taste of this beer  hit with strong Pear to begin with.  The apple (that sneaky, tempting, bastard) finds you in the finish and if you are so inclined to try, in the belch.  While I dont love all of New Glarus fruit tinged beers this one is a real winner, packed with loads of apple, spice and pear.  While one of these is enough for me I highly recommend snagging one if you can.

Bottle. Pours a glowing golden with a small white froth. Aroma is very apple forward as expected, lots of fresh apple juiciness with a nice balance of sweet and tartness. A bit of that cider spice as well. Flavor starts with an immediate burst of apple juice and tart hard cider note. Picks up a bit of apple peel and grain before a sugary sweet apple finish. Crisp light to medium body and a sharp carbonation. Very good, very cidery.

A-pours a perfectly clear light copper color with a bubbly tan colored head.

S-the nose has tons of apple juice in it with a light cider backing.  hints of spicey phenol, ever so faint.

T-same as the nose, a little more vibrant juice flavors, hints of cider behind, a touch more spice behind, a little thin in the finish on the flavor.

M-syrupy texture and rather full bodied.  high carbonation, semi dry crisp finish.

D-a little sweet and thins out in the back on the flavor but not the body.  singular but knows what it is.  Talk about an awesome halloween beer.  this would be great for a halloween party!

12 oz. bottle via trade - Pours a crystal clear amber color with a small off white head.  Faint lacing.  Aroma is lightly sweetened apples.  Well, so is the flavor.  Medium body.  A pretty nice fruit beer.  Dont think I could drink more than one though.

Keep this away from kids. Looks like apple juice, smells and tastes the same. If you have ever had fresh pressed apple juice, this is the same, with alcohol. There is no sugary sweetness that one would find in a cider. Silly good.

Lushawn sent this awesome beer labeled Unplugged Apple Ale.  Straight up apple juice nose.  Cinnamin and clove.  Not like hard cider, just Motts apple juice.  Taste is cinnamin, clove, high citrus, and apple juice.  Its not beer.  Take the hot cider grandma makes in the crock-pot, let it chill, and there you go.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2011 Bottle thanks to arminjewell. Pours apple juice color. Nose of freshly picked apples, cinnamon, brown sugar and caramel. Taste of fresh apple, cinnamon, brown sugar and light caramel malts. Light hop presence also. Very delicious beer. Solid and extremely sessionable.

This poured a cloudy yellow color with a white head. Aroma was of fresh picked over ripped apples, yum. Flavor was a bit more tart than the aroma a mix between sour and sweet apples with light funk there too. Almost ike a sweeter cider than a beer, but good stuff.
12oz bottle, out in the cold of Sexual Chocolate 2011. Aroma of straight Apple juice, this one had some interesting subtle cinnamon hints and a sweet Apple flavor. Love it!

12 oz. bottle from lushawn- thanks again, pal! Pours a bright, rich gold color with a very small white head. Aroma of ripe red apples, some light nutmeg-and-cinnamon type spices, brown sugar, sweet malts, and wheat. Flavor of ripened red apples, brown sugar, sweet malts, a pinch of nutmeg and cinnamon (am I imagining those- I dont think they were added but they come out somehow), and honey. Medium-bodied, with initially low carbonation that increases for a crisp finish. Sweet, juicy, chewy mouthfeel. This is a really cool beer, and Ive only had ciders, not any apple beers. Surprisingly nice body on this and so, so easy to drink. New Glarus dominates fruit beers.
A very nice apple ale. This reminds me of a somewhat dry apple cider. Its very crisp and bright in its flavors.
Pretty much tasted like nothing more than the best apple juice Ive ever tasted, but after all my drinking misadventures of late it really hit the spot.

Bottle poured a clear amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of carmel, apple, cinnamon and a hint of vanilla. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of apple, light carmel and a hint of spice with a crisp apple finish.

16th February 2009 Clear gold amber beer, not much head but quite good carbonation. Nice aroma of fresh apples. Taste also rings of fresh apples but also there is a well balanced counterpoint of fermented apples. Very clean, like a cider, but much smoother and without the dry acidity. This beer is what cider wants to be when it grows up!
12 p unplugged bottle.  Amber color with a medium/light head.  Almost more like a cider than a beer but over all drinkable and refreshing.

Purchased at Breeze-Thru in Milwaukee, WI; consumed on an early Sunday night while watching Divisional NFL playoffs.  Upon first sip I said "wow".  Very unique apple cider/beer combination, I know the original intent wasnt to combine but it tastes like it.  Appearance a clear amber with a thin white head.  Aroma of apples, sweetness, and ale yeast, also a bit of caramel, like a taffy apple.  Taste also like a taffy apple, sweet but not to the point of puckering which is what I typically feel from an apple alcoholic beverage, more like that caramel / apple pie sweet.  Smooth and creamy for a fruity beer, definitely a great one.

This beer tastes just like a carbonated cider. Could easy down the whole bottle with no issue what-so-ever. Has some beer characteristics in the finish but has a very juice-like feel. New Glarus makes some awesome fruit beers and this is one of the best Ive had.
UPDATED: JUL 9, 2014 Very crisp medium malt and hops. Nice flavor. But it really doesnt taste like beer. It tastes like Apple Cider. Worth drinking as a novelty once in a while
