12 ounce bottle thanks to Adam. Pours a clear dark amber color with a medium white head. A nice sweet apple aroma, reminds me of fresh cider. The flavor is very well done; smooth, crisp juicy apples, almost surprising that this is beer, no alcohol, just smooth and tasty apples, a bit of sweet malt/grain background. Very nice.

Bottle pours amber with a white head.  Aroma shows notes of, whadya know, apples.  Flavor shows the same.  Basically what you have here is a fruit beer that puts pretty much every apple cider to shame.  Bravo!

Poured into a flute.

3.5  A:  Clear light orange color.  One finger of frothy off-white head that falls pretty quickly and leaves no lacing.

4.0  S:  Sweet apple fruitiness like a sugar-laden apple cider.  Just a touch of wild apple funkiness.  Spiciness that comes off of cinnamon-like, which works well with the sweet caramel and brown sugar notes thats in there.  Smells overall like warm apple pie.  Pretty nice here.

4.5  T:  Tastes just like apple pie as well, or maybe hot spiced apple cider.  Cidery (obviously) with cinnamon and nutmeg spiciness.  Sweet brown sugar and caramel.  Not ridiculously complex, but quite tasty just like apple pie at Thanksgiving.

5.0  M:  The mouthfeel is perfect for what it is.  Lighter medium body.  Champagne-like level of carbonation and just as spritzy.  Super smooth.  Wonderful.

4.5  D:  This drinks as easy as apple cider or champagne as well.  I could drink plenty of this in a night, but would eventually like to mix in something more typical.

Bottle from Ratman.  Pours clear copper with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is average malt (bread, cereal), light hops (earthy), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of cinnamon, apple, and earth.  Flavor is average malt (bread, biscuit, cookie), light hops (earthy), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of buttered, cooked apples with cinnamon; faint crust notes.  Light body, low warmth and creaminess, medium carbonation with a dry finish.
Light gold pour with a foamy head.  Apples and yeast in the aroma and flavor.  Straightforward and delicious!

Pours clear, pale copper with a beautiful medium head composed of super-fine bubbles. Once the head recedes it leaves moderate lacing.  Strong carbonation helps bring a simply sublime sweet and tart apple aroma to your nose, like fresh cider, along with hints of spice and bread.   On the palate its like apple pie - Lush, rich, sweet, slightly tart, and appley with the underlying brown ale acting like a pie crust.  Truly fantastic stuff, but at 3.8% alcohol this one should come in 2 liter bottle for easier consumption!

Bottle courtesy of Wavers1. <3

F*** Martinellis. Period. Unplugged Apple Ale is absolutely phenomenal. Deliciously sweet and tart with absolutely no sting afterwards. SUPER smooth and goes down waaaaaay too easily.  

<3

bottle from kylie-  thanks sweetie pie.   prominent apple cider, light brown sugar, and caramel.   smell like an apple cider candle.   well made for what it is.   liked.   not something i would want to drink regularly, but can see this being a nice fall beer.   nice beer apple cider hybrid.   good.

aroma is muddled champagne metallic notes that give to utterly juicy apples. sugary sweet and tree ripe.  appearance is amazingly polished light copper with little head and just enough carb to lift without being a big burper.  flavor is mouth wateringly (literally) juicy apples with a late gritty back of the throat spice note, cinnamon perhaps.spice really lingers around the molars long after a sample. far more interesting than either belgian red or raspberry tart.

Pours apple juice colored.  Head quickly fades to nothing.  Kind of like a light, sweet cider.  Nose is sweet with apples, continues to palate.  Kind of wish it was carbed a bit more, but fun to drink nonetheless.

Bottle. Pours a clear apple cider brown. Aroma is of apple pie: caramelized apples, brown sugar, and cinnamon. Flavor is more apple juice with less of the savory qualities the nose. Tart apple juice finish. Very similar to hard cider but not as sugary sweet as most of them.

Bottle to glass. 12-23 tasting with armin and boody. (thanks to armin for bringing out the NG goodness with him from Wis)  Pours a nice light gold, with very minimal head.  Some caramel notes in there too.  Smells a lot like apple cider, with some nice caramel malt in there.  Tastes like a caramel apple at a wisconson apple fest.  Even the wife liked it, which is saying something about how fruity this tasted.  Finished just like a tart apple...juicy yet dry.  Really a nice fruit beer.

Bottle; Pour is a nice copper with a hint of amber and a modest fizzy white head that eventually rims the glass. Wonderful crisp apple aroma - What can I say - Im a huge MacIntosh/Johnathan apple fan and they really shine through here. I was surprised at how light this brew was, how palatable it was, and how awesome it was for what it is. Crisp apples put a unique bitterness in play - the "brown ale base" is so subdued but you do pick up those elements that seem uniquely New Glarus. It finishes with a sweetness as well as a general tartness. If I had a vote, Id add it to their Cherry/Raspberry stable.
Clear gold, just like apple cider. Nice apple aroma. Nice sweet apple flavor.  Medium body.  Not bad

12 oz bottle from Secret Santa.  Pours copper with a 1/2" white head. Aroma and flavor are all apple and spice.  Tart, but not to tart. Sweet, but not to sweet.  Moderate in body with lively carbonation. Very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2011 (12oz bottle courtesy of nuplastikk!!).  Pours clear copper with 1 finger head.  Aroma of fresh pressed apples.  Taste is sweet and sour, just like apple juice with some nice spices, but with a malt backbone. Light bodied with a slick, crisp texture. I dont know if a better apple beer could be made.
Poured from 12oz bottle, pours almost like a sparkling cider, aroma is sweet with obviously some apple on the nose, the flavor is decent with notes of cinnamon mixed in on the finish, decent.

Described here as only 3.8% alcohol. My bottle is an "Unplugged" version, so I hold out hope that it is more like 6-8% alcohol. Usually a beer advertised as "Apple Ale" would be a complete turn off for me, but the New Glarus label drew me in. It really does taste like apple cider, heavy on the carbonation, with an unappealing sour/bitter aftertaste.

Bottle shared by Sarah, thanks! Poured a clear gold with slight orange hue with a small white head that dissipated quickly to the edges. Aroma has a nice apple note with a bit of underlying wheat and spice coming through. Flavor started with a bit of wheat but apple quickly took over and was joined by a bit of spice in the finish. Reminded me a bit of apple cider. Another great fruit beer by NG.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Crystal clear, apple cider colored body with a quickly dissipating head of white foam.  Big, bold, complex apple fruit aroma, with notes ranging from tart, bright skins to the dark, sweeter flavors of late harvest fruit.  Hints of cinnimon and a faint cidery character.  Soft touches of graham cracker malt.  Light bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a sweet fruit flavor but dry, sparkling finish.  Carbonated apple cider with hints of lemon and mulling spices.  A mild-moderate acidity enhances the cider aspects of the flavor; the acid helps brighten and lighten the flavor as its free of any funky or aged qualities.  Not very beer-like, but the apple flavors are outstanding - red fruit, green fruit, ripe fruit, and bright fruit.
Bottle poured into flute, has the appearance of apple juice with a brilliant apple aroma.  Flavor tastes like an odd cider and there is little carbonation.  Good but not great.

Appearance:  Pours a vibrant amber gold with a small head of tight bubbles that quickly fades to nothing. The body rather clear, and leaves behind no lacing.

Aroma: Apple juice, cinnamon, light amounts of nutmeg.

Taste: Lots of apple, juicy sweet apple and tangy apple and a little bit of spice. No bitterness to be found. Really just tastes like cider to me.

Mouthfeel:  Lively carbonation, slightly sticky.

Overall:  Im sure there is barley and hops in this, I just cant find it. Its very tasty for what it is. Better than many hard ciders Ive tried.

From a bottle.  Looks like apple cider in the glass with a small bubbly head.  Subtle aroma with apples, maybe some honey, and some slight spice.  Flavor is sweet caramel with apples becoming present towards the finish.  Beer is mainly sweet with just a hint of tartness in the finish.  This is much sweeter than I had desired, and the apples seemed to play a minor role.  When the apple flavor finally hit this beer is quite nice, but it is such a small part of this beer which resembles a watery apple juice to me.

Pours deep amber/orange with thin white head, lively carbonation.  Aroma is spices, and lots of apples with a hint of tart.  Taste is sweet and tart apples up front, leading into some spices, finishing sweet and apple based.  Sort of like a cider, but really more like liquid apples than a sugary drink.  Unique, enjoyable.
Tart apple aroma. Color of apple juice-lots of bubbles right after the pour. Thin off-white head goes away quickly. Apple taste-little dry, little spicy at the end. Very refreshing and enjoyable.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2014 Amber color, actually looks like apple juice. Smells like apple juice too. Ok...tastes like apple juice...actually closer to a cider. Sweet apple dominates although there is a bit of nice tartness as well. Some underlying caramel malt. Very little hop presence. Very thin body. I donât know, I expected more from this. It has a great taste, no denying that. Apple taste is nice...very natural. But itâs just too thin...really does taste too much like apple juice. Itâs pretty good and Iâd buy it again, but Iâm a bit disappointed.

11/27/10.  12oz bottle courtesy cbfobes!  Clear amber pour with a fizzy white head thats gone fast.  Huge apple aroma with spices - reminds of cider or pie - very nice!  Very similar flavor that leans ever so slightly on the sweet side.  Otherwise, quite nice!

Notes from 11/26/2010
12 oz. bottle from Steves Madison

Ar: Lots of apple, obviously.  Fall McIntosh and tart varieties dominate.  Perhaps a touch of caramel malt.
Ap: Pours a golden amber with streaks of orange.  Not  a ton of head, but brilliantly translucent.
T: Lots of apple sweetness on the front, but not much tartness.  This would be exponentially better with a bit tart punch.
P: Champagne-like carbonation.

O: I remember this being significantly better during the last vintage (2008?).  A big tart bite would have made this one great, but it just wasnt there.

Very good beer. It has a nice head that stays and pours a beautiful coppery-red color. The apple is very noticeable, both in the aroma and the flavor. Sweet apple flavor with some dry, malty undertones, this truly tastes like an apple beer, rather than a hard cider, which I think is a good thing. Very glad they decided to resurrect this one and give it another release under the Unplugged banner. Seek it out if you get the chance.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2013 11.26.2010 Pours a light, clear brown with a 1 finger, creamy, bright white head that has decent retention. Aroma is of bright, delicious apples, sweet malt, a touch of nuts and hints of vanilla and spice, really smells a lot like apple pie. Flavor starts off with sweet, fresh apples, the apple note takes on a little more of dried and cooked apple notes along with some pie spice, faint hints of caramel, toast and a light nutty note, again, a lot like apple pie, pretty faint on the notes that make it"pie-ish," but its a delicious blend. Palate is light bodied with a creamy, slightly syrupy entry, neutral, mouth watering finish and a light, spritzy carbonation. Another masterful, delicious fruit beer from New Glarus. Despite the comparisons to apple pie I wouldnt really say this is "apple pie in a bottle," or anything, (not nearly sweet or spicy enough for one) but the spicy and malt notes lend a great balance to the sweet and slightly tart apple. 07.15.2013 Update: After nearly 3 years the freshness and any acidity of the apple taste has faded, leaving behind sweet, ripe apples and letting through a much more floral and nutty nose, and lots more caramel and nutty flavors. Still really fantastic, but very different from fresh. Unfortunately I think this is my last bottle.

12 oz. brown bottle thanks to Skyview. A golden brown beer with a small head. The aroma has apples(duh!!), but comes off as a fermented apple juice. The taste is sweet and apple and not all that different than apple juice but with some alcohol. This is a lot like a cider.

Poured a dark gold with minimal head with a light lace.  Aroma of apple juice with slight malt backbone.  Taste of apple with malt/beer background.  Overall, a good beer for both the novice and the experienced drinker.
user_location: Town of Maple Creek, Wisconsin, USA

text: Bottle.  Pour is crystal clear golden/ copper with almost no head.  Aroma is very subtle.  Light notes of apple cider and faint malt.  Really light.  Flavor is also crisp apple juice with light malty notes.  Its very solid, not overly flavorful.

Sweet spiced apple aroma. Pours an effervescent amber colored cider-like liquid. Fizzy head disappears quickly after pouring. Taste is sweet with very little maltyness. Palate is wonderfully crisp and bubbly. Very light with little alcohol, thus, it is very drinkable. Perfect for the holidays as an adult alternative to normal cider. Wont fill you up while eating a heavy meal. Nice fruit beer. New Glarus really cant be beat on fruit beers.

Bottle. Poured into a NB tulip type glass. Pours a clear copper color win a slight bone white head hat quickly coasters around the rim. The aroma is that of straight sweet apples and really nothing more. Clean, crisp apple flavor takes center stage on this one. Light mouthfeel with decent carbonation. Really there isnt too mug to say other than this is an excellent easy drinking sweet, apple flavored beer.

12 oz bottle from a coworker. Thick, hazy light copper/orange pour. High carbonation. Sweet to sour apple aroma as the body warms. Very, very sweet and thin body. Reminds me of pinto grigio. Much juicier than beer with a honey-like body. No significant finish, but a nice, thin coating is left on the throat.  Interesting brew.

Im not usually fond of fruity beer. Living in WI, I had to give this one a try as it is one of New Glarus award winning seasonals. Has a nice apple aroma to it. Its a lighter ale with a taste of apple and malt, but certainly not like some of the stronger ciders out there.

Brown-hued orange with copious white head.  Fizzy carbonation.  Aroma - straight, fresh apple with mild malt background.  Flavor is apple up front with a mild malt finish that is similar in profile to Enigma, but not quite as robust.  Light on the palate, crisp tart finish.  Easy to drink.  Not as good as I was anticipating, but good for something different.

Bottle from Discount Liquor Milwaukee.  Pours a crystal clear amber with a white head.  The head retreats quickly and leaves no trace.  The aroma is a nice apple scent.  Thin on the palate with heavy carbonation.  The flavor is an incredible balance of malt and apple.  Not cider, but not quite beer.  This is another incredible fruit beer from NG.  Cheers!
The last bottling. 2008 maybe? Its pretty much apple cider. Quality apple cider at that. Thats really all I can say. Moderate carbonation.

A: The pour is a clear amber color with minimal head formation that eventually turns into a thin layer of off-white foam.

S: Apple pie all the way on the nose. Sweet apples, notes of cinnamon, that sort of sugary pie filling glaze, and even some pie crust. A hint of cider, too.

T: The flavor isnt quite as nice as the nose, unfortunately. Sweet apples, a light butter flavor, bread/pie crust (especially on the finish), and more cider flavors.

M: The body is medium with a sort of soft carbonation.

D: Sort of like a more complex sparkling cider (non-alcoholic), plenty of sweetness and apple flavor. Id like to try this one fresher, but still good as it is.

Bottled
Clear amber color, small white head. Strong green apple juice aroma. Medium-bodied. Apple juice, light tartness, not overly sweet (no sugar added?). Nice cider/apple juice, nothing to do with beer :)
Bottled (thanks fonefan!). Amber colour, small white head. Aroma is apples, apples and sweetish sour. Flavour is very much the same. Not very exciting. Actually quite blah.

12oz bottle thanks to mikesgroove.
Appearance : Clear shiny amber with almost no head.

Aroma : Lots of apple with some acidic syrupy notes. Some cough syrup maybe. Interesting fruity notes but Im not sure about the rest.

Taste : Lots of apple, some wheat. A bit acidic and syrupy. Palate is thin. I dont think Ive ever had a beer that thin. Finish is nice apples. No bitterness. Some wheat on the finish also.

Overall : Interesting stuff. Very drinkable. Carbonation is a little bit aggressive (fizzy) but I guess it was needed to balance the thin palate. Enjoyable apple profile thats for sure but I dont think its a beer I would seek out again. Carbonation gets softer with time. Finish is a bit weak.
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 Bottle. Pours a light amber color with a big head. Flavor is straight apples - but man its good. Definitely not some watered down cider. Its delicious.

355mL courtesy of CaptainCougar. Well now we have discovered my girlfriends favorite beer taking the top spot from Old Viscosity. It poured a clear, deep gold with a small to medium, dense, creamy, buttermilk head that leaves swathy lacing if you let it. But youll probably drink the entire bottle before the lacing is even allowed to take hold. Aroma is straight chunky apple sauce, apple pie filling, rich artisan apple juice not from concentrate with beautiful caramel in the background that becomes very prominent as it warms. The finale of the nose is hot apple pie drizzled with caramel alongside mulled apple cider. Mulled spices really show through if you give it the time. Taste is not cider, not apple juice, but full creamy apple sauce, slightly apple butter, and a nice spritzy tartness gives the beer such a quenching character like Raspberry Tart and Belgian Red. It is almost impossible to keep the beer in the glass. It seems to evaporate in thin air from everyone wanting to try a sip. If there is a heaven, it would have a happy hour with $5 pitchers of New Glarus fruit beer.

12 oz bottle courtesy of secret santa, a want list item. Pours a amber-brown color with a very small off-white head that immediately fades to nothing. The aroma is mild with some apple and dust. The flavor is similar to carbonated apple cider with some mild grains and yeast. The palate is light with prickly carbonation. Finishes short and sweet. Overall: Good, but I expected more.

Bottle courtesy of braconid from TBS.  Thanks!  Pours an orangeish gold with a white head.  Head fades fast, very bubbly.  Im not sure how this is in the 98th percentile here.  Its not a bad beer, but it almost tastes more like a cider to me.  Very sharp, biting flavor, very sour - like an apple.  Crisp.  I cant see myself being able to drink more than a handful of these in a sitting.

12oz bottle, courtesy of MrPickles I think. Most recent Unplugged version, about a year and a half old? Dan said it should still be in great shape, so... Pours a lightly hazy, honey-bronze color; effervescent, almost fizzy profile in the glass; thin off-white head with light retention and lacing; attractive color. This still shows a very fresh, bright apple character in the nose, almost cider-like: sweet apples (tempered sweetness), no spicing, and a light honeyed and caramelly note, some of which Im sure comes from the age, but little suggestions of oxidation overall; great display of apple character, which is meant to be the sole focus here. Medium-light body; modest carbonation; very smooth and velvety character overall; a very, very light metallic tinge at the edges that quickly fades; lacking a bit of carbonation overall for what Id prefer, but just a great display, again, of fresh apples: modestly crisp, honeyed, cider-like without much residual sweetness at all; not bone dry, but well-balanced and dry enough without much/any balancing bitterness; perfectly presented apple character in a quite drinkable beer overall; fresh, with a touch less honey and probably a bit more carbonation, this would be awesome; definitely looking ahead to when this gets released again. Balanced finish, showing lingering apple notes, light honey, and some pear-like character.

Nice golden body with a small white head.  Light carbonation.  Aroma is pure, sweet apple juice.  Taste is not very complex either with delicious apple flavors and a slight tart finish.  The nice rich mouthfeel and full body are the best attribute... New Glarus seems to accomplish this in fruit beers like no other brewer Ive tried.

12oz bottle from Skyview. Pours clear golden orange with small white head. Aroma is apple juice with some caramel and malt. Flavors of apple juice with carbonation. Light on the palate. Extremely easy to drink. How is it that Dan Cary can make fruit beers this damn good. The next time they sell this I will buy a case of it to give to friends and family when they visit. Perfect beer to give to someone who wants to try new beers but does not like the extreme brews I crave.

Bottle 12fl.oz. [ As New Glarus Unplugged Apple Ale ]. Clear medium orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, moderate apple, sour apple, sweet apple. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate acidic with a average to long duration, apple, kunstig apple, fresh, good balanced. Body is medium, texture is oily and sticky, carbonation is soft. [20100410]

Bottle at Papsø.
Clear golden coloured with a medium sized white head.
Fruity aroma of caramel and apples.
Fruity flavour of caramel and apples.
Fruity finish.
Well made, but I dont like the combination of apple and beer.

12 fl oz bottle, courtesy of Papsoe. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is apple citric and fruity. Baking yeasty, citric and apple cake sweet and fruity flavoured. Sweet apple and malty finish.

Tasting at PapsøDeep blond color. Sweet aroma, it reminds me the perry artificial drinks from Carlsberg, in Sweden. Sweetish apple juice, with a deviation in an unpleasant direction. Mix of beer and cider? No good.
Clear amber with a tiny off white head. Aroma had apples. flavour had apples, malt and hints of spices. Finished dry.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of madmitch76. Pours a clear golden with a rough off-white head. Fresh and rather sweet apple aroma. Medium body, very sweet notes of apples and vanilla almost perfumy. No hops whatsoever. But a pleasant softdrink. 100410

Ive had many bottles of this in the past and I dont know why I havent gotten around to rating yet. Pours light golden with bright white head.  Aroma is all apples and likely would be confused with apple juice if I didnt know otherwise.  Flavor loaded with sweet apple deliciousness and tart finish.  On par with prior fruit beers from NG.  Glad they decided to make it again.

Bottle. Aroma of a 4-H farm in the autumn. Flavor a bit more complex with tart and woody character. Very interesting effort that I find myself enjoying more and more, but still have a hard time giving it much of a verbal thumbs up.

Bottle, thanks Santa!  Clear deep gold, fluffy white head that fades somewhat quickly.  Nose is apple jolly ranchers, white grapes, fresh pressed cider, a bit of a twang I often get from meads.  Flavor is Apple juice, apple jolly ranchers, a bit of fruity acidity.  It is a bit too sweet - leaving a cloying sweetness after a sip.  Its good, and really tastes like apples, but lacks the depth the other NG fruit beers Ive had.

Traded bottle poured into a flute. Clear golden, brown colour with a white head and a little lacing. Gentle aroma of green apples, caramel, candy coatings and a hint of malt. This flavour is nice sweet apples, the brown base in the middle and then finishes with some nice tartness. This was phenomenal and I liked it every bit as much as their Cran-bic.
Tasted this at Fruit Beer night at Suds Club. Its very tasty. Not too sweet and not too hoppy. None beer drinkers even enjoy it. Great fall beer.

12 oz. unplugged bottle - pours clear, light orange-amber with trace white head; sweet apples, wheat, pie crust, apple juice; drinks with a light texture and slight fruity zing; there is plenty of sweetness, but never falling into a sugary mess; pretty nice though reminding me too much of apple juice and not nearly as transcending as the raspberry tart, fruit and depth wise
New Glarus really knows fruit beers...copper pour, little to no head...nose is full of sweet apples skin...flavor is delicate, sweet, and refreshing

On tap. Pour was medium golden with a nice white head. Aroma was mostly sweet with a hint of tartness. The blend of Macintosh apples with the beer was right on making this cider-like beer complex, yet simple. Very fine brew that was a pleasure to drink.
bottle, pours clear dark gold, thin off white head.  Aroma is granny smith apple all the way.  Sweet pale malt meets apple juice.  A little bit of spice in the finish.  Pretty boring.
This is an awesome example of how an apple ale should be made. Crisp,Clean, all the thing you would expect from New Glarus, The apple equvilent to the Belgian Red..crisp and clean!

Bottle via trade thanks to badbeer on BA.  This was definitely not badbeer - it was goodbeer.  Pours a brilliant deep copper color with a small and quickly dissipating whitish head.  Aroma is really nice sweet caramel apples and spices.  Flavor is caramel, fresh apples, wheat, and mulling spices.  Sweet but never in the least bit cloying.  Really intense, complex, and well-rounded apple flavor, especially for a sub-4% ABV beer.  This would be an incredible fall beer.  Body is medium-light and palate is extremely smooth.  This is the second New Glarus fruit beer Ive had, and both have been amazing.
Bottle. Pours orange/amber, with a white head. Aroma is, duh, apples. Some caramel, too.  Flavor is apples, caramel, and a little spice. Another nice fruit beer from NG.

Bottle. Pours a slightly amber/cider color, head dissapeared almost immediately. Aroma is a subdued tart apple, sweet. I was a little worried that this was going to be a watered down version of a fruit beer. First sip changed that. This beer is like apple cider without the extreme tartness usually associated with cider. I couldnt believe how great the apple flavor came across with a touch of malt and cinnamon in the background. Finishes dry, surprising seeing how the beer is more sweet than tart.

I love apples.  Apple juice, cider, pie, jelly you name it. So, you can imagine my joy when I popped the cap off this one.  It smelled like fresh apples. Looked like apple juice, smelled like apple juice, and had a flavor profile much like a drier version of Martinellis cider.  This was a really pleasant surprise.  I dont think I have had one beer from New Glarus that I didnt enjoy.

bottle poured an amber golden color with a ring of white foam. aroma has fresh cider and green apples. thicker mouth feel than a cider with just enough carbonation to keep it refreshing. flavor has real fresh pressed cider, a light touch of malt, and is neither overly sweet or dry. this is interesting because it has all the qualities of a good fresh cider but has a bit of malted base underlying it.

Bottled. A big disappointment. This tastes pretty much like an overly malty, oxidized. Some crisp golden delicious flavors, but mostly a mush of lactic, kind of tangy wort. Not working for me, Id much rather drink a real cider.

12 oz bottle courtesy of adrian910ss. Pours a copper colour with a foamy quickly dissipating white head. Aroma of motts apple juice and not much else. Tastes like carbonated apple juice. Disappointing!!
Apple cider aroma.  Pours blonde with no head.  Fresh apple juice, cider-like, malty sweetness, spicy hops, a mild tartness, spicy dry finish.

Went on a mad beer spending spree up in Madison and bought many New Glarus products. Pours a dark orange color with off white head. Smells of a cider beer and flavor is apple cider. Not a big fan of ciders but this is pretty decent.

12 oz bottle, thanks to Ughsmash. Pours orange with faint offwhite head and almost no carbonation. The aroma is faint and cidery with a bit of a grainy hint. The flavor is pretty much like cider... apples, a little bit of spice, and a distant grain note. Decent enough, I guess, but its a cider, not a beer.

Bottle.
Clear gold like apple juice, big juicy apple aroma, flavor of apple juice all of the way through, not so much beer character behind it. Prickly, astringent mouthfeel makes it somewhat less refreshing than it otherwise could be; on the other hand, props for the <4% abv. Quite drinkable if rather straightfoward and rather concealing of its beer origins.

RBSG09 bottle at the grand tasting. Pours golden orange with a frothy white head. Big bruised apple aroma with sweet dough. Smells like fresh apple pie. Huge ice cider apple barrage, really robust fresh pressed apples. Almost tastes more like apples than apples do. Pretty delicious.

New Glarus does an awesome job with fruit beers and this is no exception.  Pour is a nice golden pour with a frothy white head but no lacing.    Aroma is...apple...duh...but not heavy, more of a light apple white wine.  Flavor is sweet but only slightly so thats nice.  Palate does wonders for this beer as its fizzy and thin.  Typically wouldnt like that but is perfect in this beer.  Overall this was just fantastic.
Pours pale straw color with a thin white head.  Smells of grannie smith blow pops.  Tastes like apple juice.  I was expecting much better given how great their other fruit beers are.

Pours out like clear apple juice with only a small white ring, no head. The nose is smells like freshed-pressed apples, and thats really it. The flavour tastes equally fresh with mild barnyard funk and floral hops. The texture is slick, lightly carbonated and sugary sweet in the finish. Basically, its like a super tasty cider. I could hardly tell that this was based on a brown ale.

12oz bottle, Unplugged label.  Clear amber orange with a two finger yellowish white head, fair retention.  Sweet apple juice up front with some toasted malts and light spice.  The flavor continues with the sweet and lightly tangy apple juice quality with some toast keeping things from getting too sweet.  Bitterness in the toasty finish was minimal.  Light prickly carbonation with a light body. Very good, easy drinking fruit beer that would drink pretty good in the summer.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle - Pours amber with almost no head. Smells just like sweet apple juice with a little bit of maltiness and a really subtle cinnamon. Theres a little more sourness in the taste, with a pretty dry finish. Theres a little bitter apple peel flavor right at the end. The carbonation bites a bit too much and its a little syrupy, but I like this one. I can see this as a dessert beer after a good meal or maybe even warmed a la Quelque Chose.

12oz bottle, 2008 edition, via trade at DLD 09. pours a clean, clear straw gold with a thin, bubbly white head and minimal lacing. aroma is, well, apples. fresh, crisp, slightly sweet pink lady apples with hints of cinnamon, pie crust, and mild earthy notes. flavor is quite good and what do ya know, apples! flavors has a more tart, granny smith element with subtle hints of grain, rye, and spice. palate is crisp and refreshing with low alcohol making this a great summer brew.

I could drink a gallon of this.  I can understand both the high ratings and the low ones too.  If you like apple juice you will like this brew.  From the first pour it looks like apple juice, it smells like apple juice, and it tastes like apple juice.  It is not the most complex beer in the world, but it is very drinkable and makes for a GREAT summer beer.

well lets start buy saying when it comes to fruit beer there is only room for one at the top and new glarus is the shit,pours a golden yellow and a  thin head aromas of apple and grains flavor of apples like drinking apple juice yes it is light on ABV but who cares crisp and clean oh yeah bottle from jjclark

Bottle at PPRBSG09.  I had been hoping to try this beer for a long time, and it didnt disappoint!  Pours a clear light orange with a small head.  Aroma of sour apple, cheese, and apple vinegar.  Flavor of fresh apples, sweet apple cider, apple vinegar, and some sour apple notes.  Very nice!
7/4/7/4/15 (3.7/5)
Bottle, pours gold with thin white head, aroma is apple. sweet apple. This is apple juice beer. taste is very sweet, almost syrupy, creamy and acidic. It does not have much beer flavor.

Wow thats appley!  Sweet red delicious apple, honeycrisp aroma too.  Clear gold, average head.  I really like the solid base which prevents the aggressively sweet fruit from spinning out of control.  Ends up being more fruit than beer, stronger character than most ciders.  Good blend of apples here.

Bottle: Deep golden with a wispy fading white head. Straight apple juice aroma- exactly apple juice- no nuance. Like a cheap cider. Crisp light palate- has a sweet burn on the back of the throat. Sweet apple flavor- only a touch of barley in the background when it warms, but you really have to dig to get it. Basically a cheap cider on the sweet side. Astringent & lacking nuance. Very disappointing.

Bottle courtesy of beastiefan2k. Pours a clear dark gold with a thin white head that collapses to a thin skin at the surface. The nose is not surprisingly dominated by apples, but it is much more subtle blend of fresh and lightly spicy (almost cider-like) notes than might be expected. Medium-bodied softly effervescent with a pleasant sweet/tart finish. The flavor is much more apple-forward than the nose, with a soft cider-like front transitioning to a blend of light malt and apple that add a bit of complexity to the sparkling cider quality that this beer undoubtedly possesses.This is a tasty beer. Thanks for the bottle, Eugene.
Looks like apple juice but Im sure thats not on purpose. Smells like apple cider. Tastes like cheap alcoholized cider too. I cant get behind this.

12oz bottle from noblesquirrel. Pours a mostly clear dull burnt orange color with almost no carbonation. Brew had kind of an oily apperance. Nose of tart apples that really remindes me of apple cider. Flavor is very tart apples, pretty damn good fruit beer.
(12oz bottle, courtesy of Bman1113vr)  Pours a clear golden body with a small white head.  Aroma of apple with a hint of cinnamon.  Tastes like a sweet apple cider.

bottle thanks to bman1113vr.  pourd gold with a thin white ring that fades away.  aroma of apple and cinnamon.  flavor for me was pretty much straight up apple juice.  medium body and medium carbonation.  this was good but just to much like juice for me, which accounts for the low overall.

bottle, thanks to bman 1113vr, apple juic color and density, small ring of foam around the glass, has a good cidery and honey aroma, flavors of apple, strawberry, honey and wet hay, good body to this, finishes well

(thanks to pepsican for this)clear orange body with a small white head.smells like fermented apple juice.flavor is pretty much the same.reminds me or sparkling apple cider.if this had some fancy yeast with a hard to pronounce name in it the cool kids would be all over it.
bottle thanks to bman1113vr.  gold pour with a ring of white froth.  nose is apples.  this is really just apple juice with a tiny bit of alcohol.

Bottle. Body-looks like apple juice with a thin ring of bubbles. Nose-cinnamon, apple juice, hard apple candy. Smells like an apple scented room deodorizer. Taste-cardboard, thin, straw, old tasting, surprisingly unsweet. Nice apple juice aftertaste. Really, this just tastes exactly like apple juice. Its good and tasty, but so is apple juice. Loses points for lacking any real depth.

Bottle thanks to BMan1113VR. Pours a clear gold with white head. Aroma of apple, close to apple pie. Flavor is the same, some faint sweetness. Mouth feel is medium body with low-medium carbonation. Overall, A very nice, enjoyable beer......

Gold pour with a creamy white head and lace. Apple is all I can say about the nose. A nice apple flavor that tastes like beer. Creamy body that borders on foamy but is not. A very unusual beer that I found appealing.

Wow, an apple a day makes a lot more sense to me now.  This is a crispy treat, not for sipping.  The quenchibility (sp?) may only be surpassed by the wonderful balance of sweet and tart.  Fruit beers are so hard to make this well.

Courtesy fantomas23. Pours a dark orange amber color with a small, bubbly white head that dissipates quickly. Some sudsy wash is left behind on the glass. The aroma is nice and filled with fresh sweet apples and apple juice. Sweet red apples and its juice dominates the flavor with some candy sugar sweetness, and a hint of tartness on the backend. Medium bodied with subtle carbonation that is very easy to drink. Pretty close to the feel of a cider. The finish is clean and crisp with the apple sweetness lingering. Very nice fruit beer and good use of the apples. Dan Carey is the master of fruit beers.
Pours light copper with a small light head.  Looks and smells like apple juice.  Taste is a subtle apple cider with a nice light malt background.  Very good.

12 oz Unplugged bottle.  Copper pour with only a thin white ring at the edge of the glass.  Aroma is tons of the sweetest, crispest apples imaginable.  Taste is very cidery at first, followed by a lovely malt finish.  Some caramel pushes the autumnal majesty even more.  Mouthfeel much closer to cider than beer; incredibly drinkable.  I prefer this to the Raspberry Tart, but nothing can touch the Belgian Red.

12oz, unplugged bottle.  Thanks ditmier.  Pours a clear golden color with a small white head.  Looks like apple juice.  Smells like apple juice.  It actually smells better and more like apples than apple juice.  Nice, juicy and sweet. Apple core, fresh, some vanilla.  Very cidery.  This doesnt have the holy-shit-awesomeness that the raspberry and cherry beers do but it is still very good.  Taste is sweet apples upfront that quickly fades to a surprisngly dry finish.  Not very beery in general.  Very drinkable.  Not as good as some of this companys other fruit beers but definitely one of the better in the style and more justification that NG brews the best fruit beers bar none.

Pours golden / amber with a white head.  The aroma has lots of crisp apple-like a cider, but heftier traits to the aroma than a cider ever does.  It has very green apple notes with a hint of malt to fill things out - delicious.  Medium / full body with a bit of nice semi-soft carbonation.  The flavor starts with full rich crispness with some maltiness to keep this from being a full blown cider taste.  The malt makes this seems more like an apple than a cider.  It is clear, refreshing and delicious.  The finish continues with everything great with the beer / cider combo taste.  Great beer and highly enjoyable.

Liquid Sunshine V. 12-oz., capped and foiled.Thanks, Kosko! Crystal clear medium amber. Virtually headless and laceless. Nice forward red apple and apple flower nose. Creamy medium body with firm carb. Big apple juice mid-palate. Mild doughy malts under that. Neutral finish. The way these guys get such beautiful flavors up front in their special ingredient beers is just a constant marvel--wheat, fruit, whatever. This is another great example.
Bottle. Very sweet one dimentional beer. Tastes like Motts apple juice with a bit of carbonation. Too sweet and not layered at all. A let down from the other superb NG beers I have had.
Nice and appley. This is an apple beer. Nice apple pie aroma. Almost cider like but has a beer like carbonation. Sweet and good.

Bottle thanks to Bman1113vr. Pours a light brown with a small head. The aroma is a pleasant mix of apple, cinnamon, butter, brown sugar and honey. The taste is apply, but not overwhelmingly so, with a nice buttery cinnamon backdrop. Effervescent mouthfeel.

Bottle thanks to Daknole (I think). Pours with a frothy, lightly off-white head over a golden body. Head leaves great lace. Aroma is spiced with slight tangy, apple pie filling with some citrus zest, simple syrup and buttered crust. This beer smells to apple pie, what Pumpking smells to pumpkin pie. Taste is sweet apples and caramelized, long duration with a sweet doughy finish. Sugary. Medium to high carbonation. Finishes dry.

CPLYFO 09.  Pours a nice slightly hazy woody amber with a thin fizzy head.  Aroma is apple cinnamon spice, apple pie, with a nice sweetness, green aplle, and a nice slight ice cider character.  flavor is also sweet, green apple, caramel sweetness, toffee, green jolly rancher, real ice cider blended with a light sweet beer, smooth and easy to drink.  3.8%?  Crap that sounds crazy- i would have thought from the nice residual sweetness it would be stronger.  This experiment sure worked out well.

My Million Beer March Tasting. Sample from a bottle shared by me thanks to Skyview.  Clear amber with a thin white head.  Aroma is apples, brown sugar, apple peels, apple sauce.  Taste is a fresh apple juice and brown sugar.

Bottle shared at the Smoke from the Oak release, I think by yobdoog.  Pours a clean golden amber color.  Aroma is sweet toasty apples, caramel, and vanilla.  Sweet and light, with a light citrus finish.  This was remarkable some sort of cider/beer thing, unlike any other fruit beer, or cider Ive had.  Certainly could drink more of this one.

Bottle from Ryan.  Thanks for this one.  Interesting concept of a beer, I have been anxious to try this one and thank God Ryan could deliver :)  Pours out a brown color without much of a head on it.  Smell is basically nothing but apple, very little, if any, hops are included in this one.  But that is to be expected.  Taste is smooth, and like cold, carbonated apple cider.  Really smooth, incredibly easy to drink.  I could probably consume my weight in this.  Nice stuff..

Bottle poured clear gold, like apple juice.  Aroma of tart apple, faint grain.  Taste is very apple, very tart, with some light grain, though very faint.  This is easier drinking than several apple juices.  Very crisp and refreshing.  I havent had too many fruit beers, but this one seems to be three parts fruit, one part beer.  Overall, very refreshing, tastey brew.
Pours chill hazy amber, with some malt aroma and a flavor dominated by tart apple, wheat and touch of oak.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Petrucci914.  Pours a clear apple juice color with the smallest of white films for a head.  The aroma is apple, apple, and more apple, sweet and pleasant.  The flavor reminds me of when my grandpa would pile all of the grandkids in the hunk of junk and drive us to Rousters to sit in front of the fireplace and drink the fresh apple cider.  I enjoyed this as much for the flashback as the beer itself.

Bottle: Yum, yum in my tum.  I could drink this for breakfast with my eggs and toast.  It has a clear cider look with aromas and flavors of tart green apples.  Its all apple, you almost forget there is alcohol in it.  I picture hobbits drinking this a lot.
Bottle unplugged.  Nice golden hue, aroma buttered popcorn and apple.  Taste is apple juice/cider with some spice aftertaste.    Not bad.

Bottle (Unplugged Apple Ale) Pours out a crisp clear gold apple juice. Topped with no head. Just a very nice apple aroma. the Aroma was of sweet apples and a touch of spice. The tast was juice all apple juice all the time. Crazy sweet and a hint of spice. Thanks Toby

12 oz bottle courtesy of discount liquors (milwaukee, wi). Pours a nice sustained golden hue, transparent, with moderate bubbly white head that dissipates to a film, well carbonated. Laces well, surprisingly. Aromas are a nice apple feel, crisp, good sweetness, with grainy notes. Apple sauce? Yum. Initial is a nice apple sweetness, nothing cloying, with some mellow grainy sweetness. Largely, a mellow apple juice / apple sauce feel. Finishes crisp but sweet, flavorful. Very nice and sessionable.

Bottle:  Bright gold and ciderlike in appearance.  No head.  Smells like apple juice and tastes like apple juice.  Sweet and fruity with some mild carbonation.  Barely a hint of cidery type spices in the tail.  Uninspiring.
Thanks to John at Boulevard for sharing this beer. Pours a muscat color. Aroma of apples, reisling and tojkai. Flavor is rich and fresh apples. Dry, smooth finish..very nice beer.

12oz bottle 3/13/09 (Discount Liquor)-Pours a clear copper color with a small white head that dissipates rather quickly into a small ring. Aroma of apple cider. Taste of apples and more apples. This light bodied brew is very well balanced and very tasty.

Pours out like a crisp apple cider color with thin bubbly head. Aroma is intense apple cider aroma with floral bouquet. Taste is like apple sauce and apple pie turned into carbonated liquid. The mouthfeel is great, its not to cloying or imbalanced. Good stuff. Wish I had more!

Bottle (thanks much noncaloric).  Pours a clear lightish copper with a small white head.  Aroma is, yes, you guessed it, apple.  Lots and lots of apple.  Some slight floral notes as well.  Flavor is apple...more specifically apple cider.  Sweet but with a dose of tartness.  Just like a good apple should be.  Quite a tasty treat.  The wife REALLY liked this one, but found it hard to believe it is actually beer.

2008 Bottle - thanks buckybeer! - Pours a thin lt gold with a quickly dissipating white head...aroma is pure apple nectar, vanilla...flavour is similar, sweet apples with a tart, lingering finish...has a creaminess about it that I cannot explain...delicious experience...

bottle from thecheeseman: pours a golden apple juice colour, who would of thought, with a small white head. aroma is full of apple meat and the skins, also a great floral aroam that matches apple blossoms. the flavour is great just like fresh apple juice with a slight sweetness and just awesome apple flavour. finishes very nice with a small amount of tartness. great beer. wish i had more.

Clear coppery brown with a thin film of a head.  To get an idea of the aroma just take a Red Delicious and take a big whiff.  Thats exactly what youre getting from this beer.  Flavor of fresh cider with a bit of tartness to keep the sweetness from overwhelming the brew.  Crisp, dry, sweet finish that lingers for some time.  I couldnt drink a lot of these but its a nice change of pace.
This was a very crisp beer. The apperance was a nice clear cider. The flavor was perfectly ripe apple. I really enjoyed the appely crispness of the beer. Ised it came in packs more than 4 at a time.

This pours with a small and quickly dissipating head and is almost still, with a nice clear golden color. The aroma is of nice red apples very straightforward and very nice. I like the flavor quite a bit. I honestly expected a sweet tart cider sort of thing, I was very glad that this was not so much the case. This tastes like fresh red apples; Ive had the fresh cider from Gays Mills where the apples for this beer come from and it is not surprisingly very much like that cider in flavor. There is also a nice tartness that is seemingly coming off the base beer much more than it is coming from the apples. This has very little green apple sourness or tartness, which is cool. I expected a little more jolly rancher than I got and Im happy that that isnt so much the case. What can I say, plenty of fresh apples a nice zing of tartness overall just a wonderful little beer.

Aroma. Wow. Aroma.  Yeah.  It has one of those.  
Lots of sweet apple, flowers and honey. 
Taste is bright, sweet apple.  Like a Honey Crisp apple had sex with a flower.  
Straight up apple.
More apple.
No alcohol in this bitch.
Finish is clean, slightly dry.
I would love to have this in a juice box in my sack for lunch.  
Yes.

Bottle, a gift from Daknole! Clear copper with scant white head. My first sniff is Jolly Rancher apple candy. But it makes me want to drink! Has far more complexity than first greets the nose, too. Beneath the candy is some burnt caramel, a nice brown sugar/butter blended fresh in a hot pan, or apple butter. Also tartness and from the fruit aromas. The mouthfeel is prickly and champagne-like. This is a dessert-like beer with an addictive vanilla fudge-like finish that adds complexity. Very sweet but good. Its well-constructed brew that transcends its sweetness, even if I do need to wash my mouth out with hops afterwards!
Pours a clear light copper with a small white head.  Strong aroma of apples, cinnamon and apple flavored hard candy.  Taste of apples and cinnamon.  Like drinking a candy beer.

Pours a clear glowing darker golden with a odd big bubble white fizzy head.  Smells like sweet apple candy.  Wow! Tastes like apple candy as well.   Sweet, tart and very pure.  Definitely the best apple beer Ive ever had.   Has an authentic mashed apple flavor that tastes like its in hard-candy form.  Apple Jolly Rancher... its identical.   Not much in the terms of "beer" flavor.   One of these is enough as it accomplishes its desired intention.  Medium/light body with big corse sharp carbonation, appropriate for flavor.

Tasted 2/18/09.  12oz bottle.  Even from about a foot away, I could still smell the apples as I poured.  Filtered with a copper hue.  Trace ring of off-white head.  Aromas of apple juice and a slightly musty note.  Medium bodied and super sweet.  Zesty effervescence.  Moderate malt backbone, but the apple essence overpowers all else.  Trace bitterness in the finish.  This is better than most ciders Ive had, but still a little too sweet for my tastes.  Im sure this is wonderful in the summertime.
bottle. unplugged series. pours golden with white head. nose of fresh green apples. flavor has a nice balance of tart and sweet green apples. tastes like a great cider but really not my thing.

Bottle received from my brother in law as a gift (Thanks Neil!)   Pour was clear golden yellow, little carbonation and tart granny smith apple aroma.  Flavor was very sweet, almost like the sour apple gum youd by at the corner store when you were a kid.  Overall a decent beer, but I wouldnt drink more than one in any given night.

Bottle courtesy KingpinIPA.  Pours golden with small white head.  Smells of cider and apple tart.  Taste is apple up front with bready notes throughout.  I dont know now else to categorize this other than a great combination of cider and beer.  tasty.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2010 Re-rate.  2010 bottle.  Courtesy zimmerbloke.  Dark gold color, good full white head, decent lacing.  The aroma is sweet apple pie.  Smells just like the apple pie we had today for Thanksgiving.  The flavors are soft and a bit creamy and tart.  Vanilla and soft caramel compliment the sweet apple.  The palate is a little thin.  Another good fruit beer from New Glarus but I much prefer the Belgian Red and Raspberry Tart to this one.  Original Rating:  Courtesy of pfoxyjohn. Pours a clear copper color with a thinish white head. Lively carbonation. Very soft on the palate with tart apples and just the right amount of sweet malt to prevent it from feeling like a cider. Very well-rounded, crisp, and refreshing. A tasty fruit beer, my wife loved it too, we ended up sharing this one. Thanks pfoxyjohn!

12oz bottle.  Pours a nice copper color with some white head that lingers around the edge of my glass in a thin ring.  Nose is pure apple juice.  Taste isnt overly deep or dense, but is pure apple with some hints of wheat.  Very enjoyable, easy drinking and refreshing.
A very apple juice aroma. This is extremely heavy on the apple flavor. Almost more so than most ciders. Okay for a fruity beer, not great.

Once again, bottle courtesy of Juart.  Pours amber golden with a small frothy off-white head.  Aroma is a tart malty apple juice.  A little sweetness in the taste, but really has a lot of apple character.  Pretty dry overall.  Some tartness carries from the flavor to the taste.  Has a lot of tight effervescence.  And excellent balance with this beer.  Finishes with a decent richness.  Not too fruity.  Very well done.
Bottle shared by dkachur 01/18/2009. Clear dark golden. Flavor like a Appel Jolly Rancher. Light body and mouthfeel. Fizzy sweet jello like finish.

Bottle via noncaloric, huge thanks.   Pours a golden color with a nice sized sparkling white head.   Aroma is all frsh apples.   Flavor is apples, light caramel, hint of citrus.   Palate is light bodied, medium to high carbonation, finished mostly sweet, with some tartness.   I just can help but love this.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2009 Thanks ton noncaloric for this bottle!  Clear copper pour with fizzy off white head.  Aroma of fresh apples.  Refreshing vibrant flavor. Caramel, apples, and light hops.  Highly drinkable, but a little sweet on the finish

12 oz. bottle, courtesy of Skyview.  Pours a clear gold color.  Thin, bubbly white head.  Aroma of apples and cinnamon.  Initial bit of apple sweetness with tons of sugar, but this gives way to a nice malty touch.  Finish is surprisingly clean.  Very interesting beer.
A wonderful apple aroma. A pleasant change to those who are used to apple ciders.

Unplugged 12oz via tytoanderson, thanks so much Ty.  The original eluded me forever and Ive been dieing to try this.  Shared with my gf over dinner, tofu kabobs and some king root roast thing.  Pours orange with a bright white ring.  Nose is rich like spiced cider.  Taste is sweet and light and full of refreshing apple flavors.  Its close to a cider indeed but has some refreshing high levels of carbonation.  Nice.

From bottle courtesy of dpjuart. Great apple juice aroma. Starts with light tart character. Light malt character but mostly like a cider. Rich golden amber clear with thin white head. Medium watery body with medium carbonation. Lovely apple flavor in and out with mild crisp fruity hops. Sweet and fruity and very refreshing.

Very good, but not entirely what i had in mind. Fun. Could call it a soda. Fruit beers are hard to gage. Some are just hints of the fruit flavor and others...(this) are overwhelming in flavor....and overwhelming in sweet. Though, if a beer is called apple ale it should have apple flavor. Perhaps just too sweet for me. I believe that alcohol should be a little more difficult to consume than this beer. Good in the winter. grown up apple juice.

Bottle graciously sent as an extra by my main man pantanap. Thanks buddy! Pours a beautiful clear, dark golden color. Lovely crisp aroma of fresh-cut apples, grains and cider spice. Taste is very similar to apple cider with a bit more attention on grainy malt tones. Thin body, but very refreshing on the finish. Nice and crisp, very drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2009 Pours dark golden with a thin white head. The nose was apples and a touch of nutty influence. The flavor was the same a=but a bit more refreshing. Apples, more over, apple skins, is what stood out.

Bottle from skyview. This stuff was really tasty. The aroma is of fresh apples, some caramel, and toasty brown ale base. Pours a golden brown with a thin non lasting head. Very nice apple cidery flavors up front. Tart, crisp, refreshing apples. This is followed by an ever so light brown ale base that is a little toasty and nutty. Really nice lasting crisp apple flavors. This was really enjoyable.
Thanks aspidites.  Pours light amber brown, sweet, tart, apples, apples, apples, little caramel, slight malt.

This Unplugged NG pours a clear golden amber with a small white head that quickly drops to a cap. Some wispy lacing. Aroma of McIntosh apples, graced by caramel and Granny Smith greenies. Crisp and clean light body. Tastes like a topnotch cider in spite of the brown ale base. Very natural tasting and not at all cloying. Loads of fresh McIntosh flavor, accented by a touch of caramel malt. Some green apple tartness but this is more red apple sweet than tart. Excellent!

12oz bottle thanks to Daknole and Pantanap.  Pours cider in color with a ring of foam.  Aromas of apples and cherries.  Flavors of apples, tart fruit, and a nice sweet finish.  Palate is medium bodied an perfectly carbonated.  This beer is all about apples, take it for what its worth and it is awesome!  Looking for something more complex then look elsewhere.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass.

Pours a clear and very bubbly golden with a small white head that stays on as a ring as the bubbles continue to stream up from the bottom.

The aroma is, not surprisingly, dominated by apples and it smells like a really strong apple cider or fresh apple juice.  Hints of caramel malts are dominated by the sweetness.

The first sip is a blast of tart apple sweetness that zings the tongue before the caramel malts show up briefly.  The finish is very sweet with the apples but also has a slight bitterness that lingers into the aftertaste.

The mouthfeel is well carbonated with lots of sugary sweet apples coating the palate and slightly dry.

This is another great fruit beer from New Glarus who certainly know their way around these styles.  The drinkability may be slightly limited due to the massive sweetness, but its still a great fruit beer.

12oz bottle courtesy of ughsmash, light orange color, looks like apple juice. First whiff is apples and apple juice, surprise! Smells really sweet, not sure if I like it. Very strange taste, like the malts are wrestling the apples for control of the beer. Not a bad beer at all just very, very weird.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-27-2009 03:33:42

Bottle.  Poured a pink-tinged golden color with a short-lived, thin off-white head that diminished to a light ring.  Aroma of red apples, cherry pie filling, some sugary sweetness, and a faint wheatiness.  Smooth, lightly sweet entry with some tart hints of apple that finishes with a cidery sweetness.  Low carbonation, sweet on the palate.  Overall, too one dimensional for my tastes.  It seemed more like a sweet cider.  Ill stick with the Berliner weiss.

Bottle courtesy of Gillard. Pours a clear amber color with virtually no head. Aroma is decidedly fruity and sweet with strong notes of apple, apple cider, and some sweet honey and caramel notes. Flavor is sweet and syrupy with notes of citrus, apples, apple cider, pear, fresh floral overtones. Generally light-bodied with a sweet and syrupy finish.

12 oz bottle.  Crystal clear copper with a thin white head.  Nose is apple juice and dough, faint toffee.  Really interesting.  Not quite a cider and only in the finish reminding me of a beer.  Crisp but not sharp, juicy with light drying.  Taste is mostly apple, some cherry, a bit of cinnamon, faint lemon pith and apple peel.  I wanted to be challenged but this was still good.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2009 12oz Bottle. Very very interesting nose that combines fresh apple cider, 

with the deeper husky parts of the malt, and the softer sides 

of apple cider vinegar. Complex and enticing. Pours a crystal 

clear vibrant bright orange fire, bubbling as champagne and 

lifting an edge of white to the corners of the glass. Flavor is 

high and fluffy, bringing a delicate, blossoming rich apple 

character to my lips. So sweetly perfumed, yet not cloying. 

This is awesome. The malt stiffens the backbone of the beer. 

Incredible elegant grace. A calvados like alcohol brims over 

the glass edges and adds an edge of refinement to the finish. I 

cannot imagine a more perfect marriage of apple and ale. Soft, 

light and airy. A heavenly beer.

My liquid christmas card from Kimber. Pours a clear golden with a tiny white head. Smells of stearin with a hint of apple juice. Sweet with aromas of applejuice. Medium bodied. Tiny hints of stearin. Quite high carbonation. Crispy dry finish. Reminds me of a cider with a bit more body.

In short: An apple pie in a bottle.  Light and extra clean.  It is what it is, a little oddity fun in small quantities.
How: Bottles, 2008 unplugged release.  Bottles received from MatSciGuy, thanks a lot Levi.  Consumed fresh and shared at tasting session with Montreal crew.
The look: Clear golden body with almost no head
In long: Nose of apple pie with cinnamon.  Taste is really apple pie with cinnamon, crisp crust and all.  An overall sensation of crumble.  Medium carbonation, very light body.  This is a very very clean beer, a bit too sparkling clean for my liking.  This beer has very little body and the mouthfeel is rather boring.  I understand its a 3.8% beer but New Glarus have proven they can make nourishing full body fruit beer with a similar gravity.  Also while this original taste is kind of fun the first few sips it quickly gets tiresome.  On one hand I admire the originality of this offering but on the other hand this is not something I could drink regularly or in large quantities.  So I have mix feeling about it like a cheap fat Texan standing in front of a free all-you-can eat fruits and vegetables buffet.

Bottle courtesy of Gillard. Pours an apple juice golden color with a small off-white head.  Nose is apple cider, sugar, spice, butter, and goodness.  Flavor is red, green, and yellow apples with cinnamon/sugar spice, and it finishes smoothly with a wonderful Grandmas house feeling.  I can imagine this beer on a cold Wisconsin afternoon. Very nice.

Bottle courtesy of dkachur on 01/18/2009. Clear golden copper body with a medium creamy off-white head. Huge green apple aroma with lots of sugar. Big apple juice flavor with spicee and sugary notes. Medium light body with moderately high carbonation.

Unplugged bottle from Winter 08 from Piggly Wiggly in North Kenosha. Pours amber colored/apple juice looking. Fizzy disappearing head, like a fizzy cider. Nose is fresh apple juice and some light beer notes of sweet malts. Pretty pleasant. Taste is sweet and definitely apple flavored. Beer is super effervescent. Aftertaste melds into a cider finish with malt taste. Definitely not dry, sweeter than Id expect. Interesting, though more like an alcopop than beer, really.

Bottle in trade with noncaloric. Dark golen amber. Rich sugar apple and musty/yeast aroma. Tastes like the scent. Very apple cider-like. Big apple flavour. Sweet in a brown sugar quality. Would be hard to pick out from apple cider in a side by side. A bit of an edge to the taste musty or yeasty.

Bottle shared by JCB. Thanks Jason.  Been wanting to try this forever.  Nose is sweet candied apple, honey, fresh apple cider. Flavor is a bit on the sweet side from what I would have liked, but it still tastes very natural and is not cloying at all.  Wish it was a bit more carbonated and dry.  Good, but not the great beer I wanted it to be.

Bottle shared by JCB.  This is a great low-alcohol treat.  Tastes and smells pretty much just like apple juice or apple cider.  Smell a bit deeper, though, and there are some slight apple pie notes... the slightly caramelized brown sugar and flaky crust... theyre subtle, but I think theyre there.  Fun beer.

Courtesy TheCheeseMan.  Clear golden color, very little head.  Crisp apple with some caramel, a malt presence made more apparent since crisp apples are usually associated on my palate with ciders.  Mild apple notes on the taste, slight sharpness balanced by sweetness.  Pretty tame, but well done.

12oz bottle courtesy of OSLO.   Clear, golden apple juice color with a small white head.   Juicy, sweet and lightly tart apple aroma.   The flavor follows with what could be non-alcoholic cider, but it perhaps just a bit less cloying.   This was definitely not agreeing with me by the end.   I wish it were dryer.

Bottle, courtesy Kevin. Pours a copper cider color,with fizzy white lacing. Aroma is pure apples, with brown sugar, red wine, some grapes. Flavor is again all apples (shockingly) with caramel, honey, brown sugar. Very nice. Smooth, medium-bodied, and incredibly drinkable.
12 oz bottle. Color is like light maple syrup, head is pretty minimal. Definite apple aroma. Tastes a lot like apple cider. Very bubbly mouthfeel.

(12oz bottle, thanks OSLO) Crystal clear apple juice body topped by small white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, crisp apple, light tartness.  Taste is medium sweet, apple.  Light-medium body, some fizziness.

Courtesy of OSLO. Clear pale golden body with a small white head. The nose is fresh pressed cider with just a touch of cotton candy and honey. Wow, that is really an incredible nose. The taste is moderately sweet and lightly tart. The flavor is a bit of a let down after the nose, with it being more like watered down cider. Medium/light body is a tad thin with a spritzy mouthfeel.

12oz bottle from woodmans, kenosha.... a crystal clear light orange brown with a thin and quickly dissipating white head.... aroma of sweet assertive fresh apple scents that really smells quite nice and appealing....flavors were more apple juice in nature with moderate carbonation.  pretty sweet overall and not too much complexity involved. really drinkable and i can see this appealing to the masses.

12oz from MatSciGuy - thanks, Levi!! Man, can New Glarus get any more rad? We had a big NG night at the tasting and my already sizable estimation grew during the evening. A big Granny Smith nose to this fine buttery golden beer, with its crisp carbonation. Lively mouthfeel. The initial sips are cider all the way, but as you get into it there is definitely a creamy, sweet quality that emerges. Hard not to say that its pie-like. And what kind of sick bastard doesnt like pie?

Thanks a ton to JCB for sharing and whoever gave it to him. Pours a translucent gold with a frothy white head. The nose was just as expected, very tart apple, nice background spice character, very pungent. The flavor is spicy, very strong apple flavor, pie spices, very nice. Sweet and crisp on the mouthfeel with a mild tartness. It is what it is and is very tasty in the way it does it.

It pours a clear golden copper; effervescent, with a bubbly white head that quickly disappears.  I’m not too sure what the difference is between an apple cider and an apple ale, but it tastes pretty similar, only a little lighter on the palette and the alcohol than the ciders I’ve tried.

Bottle. Clear golden color, a few strands of carbonation emanating up from the bottom. Thin wispy head. Flavor is big fresh apple notes, some golden delicious and also Macintosh. Dry to begin, sweet medium, dry finish. Flavor is so big and fresh that you can taste a bit of apple rind in there. Wow, this is like some exceptionally good apple juice. Well done. New Glarus does fruit beers like no other.

Pours a clear copper gold with light white head. Aroma is similar to cider with the sweet apples and light notes of cinnamon. Flavor is sweet and tart apple with brown sugar. Medium body with quite a bit of carbonation. Very well done beer.

12 ounce bottle brought to me from Wisconsin by a friend. Thanks Jenny! Pours a clear light orange color with a medium head. Good head retention that does not leave much lacing. Aroma is strong, tart apple cider. Subtle graininess is there if you look for it, but the apples do dominate. Flavor is apple cider with a tart champagne like finish and some spices. Full bodied and very smooth with lively carbonation. This is very nice.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear, light brown color.  Slight off-white head, dissipates quickly.  Aroma is mainly sweet apple, with a hint of malt as well.  Flavor is very cidery, sweet apples again, with a malt finish.  Hints of cinnamon at the end as well.  Palate feels effervescent, very lively on the tongue, and a bit syrupy.  Overall this is an excellent fruit beer, a great brew for my 100th also!

Pours deep clear gold with wafer thin white head. Big apple nose of huge sweetness that gets near the sense of maltiness deep in the background. Wow. The taste is much the same with rich deep ripe apple flavors that scream robustness but are very smooth and near refreshing. Just as the initial tidal wave of apple goodness peaks a tingle of carbonation adds a little extra oomph to the experience.  Very nice cider.

New Years bottle.  Pours an orange amber body with a thin white lacing.  Doesn’t taste like beer it tastes like apple juice.  Apple skins, a late harvest cider, malty apple juice.  I could have gone for some more tartness to balance out the body.

Lots of hype surrounding this one in these parts.  Bottle, pour is somewhat effervescent, cloudy yellow/goldish, not much of a head.  ARoma of apples, mostly like apple cider/juice.  Taste is pretty much that too with a little wheat that comes in the finish.  Medium to light bodied.  Meh, not really my thing.  Tastes mostly like apple cider.

Very pleasing aroma greets your nose, Great clarity with just the right amount of effervescence.  Excellent blend of apples and beer. Good for special occasions.  Enjoyed by all at ours. Another winner from New Glarus.

Another good fruit beer from New Glarus. Definately fruit is there specialty. This beer makes me glad I live in Wisconsin. Great apple taste throughout. Some notes of vanilla and a good tartness that leaves you needing the next sip.

Bottle courtesy of Ed at Heritage Liquors. Pours a welcoming cider color with no discernable head.  You can smell the apples from across the room.  Tastes like the best apple cider ever, but at 3.8% I felt let down.  Put this in a brandy barrel or you might as well put a straw on the side.  Otherwise, its gonna get used in a sauce.

Bottle from Heritage splitsies with nbutler11.  Full aroma of Braeburn and Granny Smith apples with hints of vanilla and light spice.  Deep golden color.  Flavor as above, but I am of the mind that fruit beer is easy to make good with a sub-4 ABV.  This maybe would be best as part of a reduction...
Bottle. Pours a copper cider brown with a small white head. Lots of apple cider to the nose. Same apple cider flavors with nice hints of vanilla and very slight oak. Incredibly smooth mouth. Tasty!

courtesy of cigarcitybrew.
Could this one replace my New Glarus all time fav. of Belgian Red? They are so close, and so unique in their style.
New Glarus has once again top the quality with this ale.
Pours copper with thin white head.
Aroma is loaded with the bubbly nose of apple juice, close enough to remind me of an excellent cider. New Glarus is not joking around with the fruits, and they are using some fine apples.
Taste is loaded with apples and very faint malts. Not only do we get some fine apple taste, there is also a very light bitter feel of the apple skin. The whole is mixed with a very light bubbly finish.

Pours a sparkling copper with a white head. Aroma smells like apple cider and cinnamon. Tastes a lot like fresh, sparkling apple cider, with a bit of malt and bitterness in the finish. Pretty awesome.

Bottle courtesy of Retorp by way of TheCheeseMan. Pours a pale copper with a small white head. Aroma is strait up Red Delicious, not much else but it smells like fresh pressed red apples. Taste is the same as aroma with a hint of sweet malt in the finish. Medium mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness. Very good.

Courtesy TheCheeseMan.  Fresh 2008 Unplugged version.  This clear bodied brew is copper in color, crowned with a fluffy pillow of smooth, beige colored foam.  A soapy wash of sugary lace dries to minimal, jagged lines and spots.  The aroma is simple, but inviting.  Freshly pressed red apple juice dominates, with subtle hints of soft oak an vanilla falling in line.  Sweet Macintosh apple flavors pair well with mild caramel and just a dash of spicy cinnamon, while a hint of green apple tartness comes through on the finish.  Just shy of medium bodied, there is ample cidery sweetness to the mouthfeel, with a sharp tingle of active micro-bubbles.    Save for the frothy head, there is probably no way I could distinguish this from a cider.  Dan Carey can carve another notch int his fruit beer championship belt.
Foremented apple cider flavor dominates the brown ale but it hard to complain it is so delicious. Nearly too sweet but come out on top.

Courtesy of TheCheeseMan. Wow, apples. This pours like apple juice, golden, slightly fizzy, head is nowhere.  Aroma of apple juice, some apple skins, a little spice. Taste is apple cider all the way with some cinnamon, caramel and spiciness. Sweet, a little tart in the mouthfeel, low carb with some prickly bubbles, a little dryness. Excellent. Hard to believe there is malt in there, very like cider.

Poured golden with no head. Apple cider aroma. Tasted much like sparkling apple juice. Very sweet. Maybe a hint of malt. Does not taste much like beer, but definitely a nice change of pace. Once again New Glarus comes up with an interesting and tasty fruit beer.

12 oz, Unplugged version, courtesy of General Gao. Clear, new-copper color with a small disc of bubbles. Aroma of crisp, sweet-sour green apple. Flavor is the same with the addition of light toffee and faint nutshell at the finish. Light-medium body is fizzy and tingly.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear golden/yellow color with a small had that could use some more retention and lacing is ok.  Aroma is well.....apples.  Big green apple nose with a slight hint of spice.  Flavor is sweet apple up front with a touch of almost caramel and cinnamon at the end.  Its almost like caramel dipped apples.  The thing I like the best about it is that it very different from a cider. Its a nice mix of apples and beer.  Another winner for New Glarus and fruit beers!

Pours a light amber with a frothy white head. Aroma is very sweet with candy and cinnamon. Flavor is sweet but also has an apple tartness at the same time. Light bodied, very sticky texture. A very good beer, the fruit is not overpowering but instead compliments the malt, yeast and hops.

Appearance of apple cider with a thin white head that is gone faster than I can type this sentence.  Aroma of apples, cinnamon and malt.  Taste of apples, cinnamon, malt.  Smooth and tart but a bit too much like apple juice.

Bottle from KingpinIPA. Pours fizzy orange gold with a white head. Sweet apple aroma, very crisp. A touch of some sweet caramel malt. The flavor is very cider like, sweet apple with a light tart tinge, very fresh, brown sugar and caramel. Extremely drinkable.

12oz bottle. Poured a clear medium orange color. The head was soapy and off white. Some tattered lace was left behind on the glass at the end. Pretty simple aroma. Straight up apple cider. Light to medium bodied and sweet with delicate carbonation. Apple cider dominated the flavor, but I also tasted hints of pale malt and toffee in the background. Very easy drinker.

12oz bottle from badbeer. Pretty much what daknole said. Apple cider with the slightest beer flavor finish. Pours clear copper amber with a very thin, fizzy white head. Smells like apple cider. Tastes like apple cider mixed with a malt beverage. Very nice. Medium body, crisp carbonation.

Bottle from noncaloric.  Thanks so much.  Pours a nice golden color with a quickly disappearing white head.  Aroma is crisp and clean and apples apples and more apples.  Flavor is a shocker APPLES.  Tart and sweet with one thing that differentiates this from ciders it actually finishes with the slightest beer flavor.  A wonderful change of pace and my wife will be very happy.

Really looking forward to this going in...pours a clear copper color with high level of effervescence and a fairly strong white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is all about spicy apple cider, but there is something else in there, maybe some clove, or cinnamon...either way, very nice, and a step above any ciders I have tried.  Flavor is both sweet and tart apple, caramel malts, a hint of wheat, and a brown sugary flavor that kicks in near the ends...beautiful...just what I pictured.  Superbly drinkable...if I rated palate solely based on drinkability, this would be the easiest 5 ever, but it is a bit more carbonated than I would like.  Biggest qualm...the fact that NG made this their unplugged offering, because at this ABV and this drinkability, a 4 pack can disappear quite quickly.  Next time, make this the standard offering and the Alt the unplugged version...Prosit

[Bottle] Pours a clear deep gold with a small head of large bubbles that dissipates quickly. Aroma is fresh squeezed apple juice, somewhere between tart and sweet. Flavor is very much like a really nice fresh apple juice with the finish revealing that it is still in fact beer, with a lingering maltiness with a little touch of tartness. Easily the best apple brew Ive come across, and even my girlfriend likes it - thats a compliment to be sure.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2009 Well if anyone drinking this could ever tell this from a really good apple juice, i would be shocked. Bascially the beer equivilant to biting into a fresh, Door county apple. Goes down really fast. I really dont get any beer like qualities at all in this, but being a fan of apples in general, this was up my alley. Compared to Furthermores Fallen Apple, this was far and away better.

thanks to cmubeerman, i’ve had this a few times now.  it’s pretty straightforward pure apple beer, but it’s good, too.  3.8%?  pathetic, but i guess that’s the point.  it basically tastes like carbonated apple juice.  candyish.  hardly any beer character, although andrew says that comes out more when its colder.  damned drinkable, tho.

thanks goes out to pfoxyjohn for this thanksgiving day treat... Pours a dark tan autumn brown ... good white foam ring... wonderful fresh bitten apple scent ... is so delicious, i can never enjoy a cider again because this is what an apple libation should be, no more - no less, the standard if you will... i vote the apple to be the fruit of the year!

Ok, maybe more of a cider then a beer but damn, this stuff is just pure greatness.  There is enough caramel malt finish that you get the beer part and it gives it a caramel apple finish.  Just pure drinkability, and I will go through all the cases I bought in no time.  Amazing.

Aroma is apples, sweet and a little musty.  Pours a clear orange, thin white head spotty lace.  Flavor is more and more apples, a little more cider than ale, but oh, the is palate so there, dry, chalky prickly, puckering.  The beer is really more to be felt than tasted.

12oz bottle split with Ann.  Clear, filtered orange color.  Cidery, and full of apple taste. A little weak in ABV and body, but the full, natural apple taste is really quite impressive.  Good stuff, but lacks a touch of depth.  That said, this stuff is paradise juice.

12 oz bottle shared by John.  Pour is the color of cider, orange golden, cloudy, then turned pretty clear, with a smallish white head.  Aroma of sweet apples, again, very much cider.  Taste is the apples, sweet, cidery. Well made, but pretty much all about apples.  Thanks John
Crushed with Jakebra.  Kinda like the middle of those suckers with the caramel without the caramel, and its beer instead of candy, which makes it excellent.  A great fruit beer.
